REASONS FOR DECISION
INTRODUCTION
[1] XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX (the claimant) is a 43-year-old married male citizen of Egypt and holds no other citizenship.
[2] The claimant claims refugee protection pursuant to ss. 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)1 based on his religion (Christianity).
[3] This claim was considered by way of an expedited process.
[4] Paragraph 170(f) of the IRPA2 provides that the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) may allow a claim for refugee protection without a hearing unless the minister has notified the RPD of the minister's intention to intervene within the time limit set out in the Refugee Protection Division Rules.3 Further, subsection 162(2) of IRPA4 directs each Division to deal with all proceedings before it as informally and quickly as the circumstances and the considerations of fairness and natural justice permit.
[5] The claimants' case was identified as one that could be processed through the Instructions governing the streaming of less complex claims at the Refugee Protection Division.5 The RPD, on the date of issue, has publicly identified claims from Egypt as being able to be accepted without a hearing.6
[6] The RPD received a Certificate of Readiness, File Review Process form signed on 3 December 2019 (Exhibit 4).
[7] Front End Security Screening (FESS) was received by the RPD in this case on 23 November 2019.
[8] Having carefully considered the evidence in this case, I find that it meets the criteria for expedited determination. This case has therefore been decided without a hearing, according to the Instructions governing the streaming of less complex claims at the Refugee Protection Division.
ALLEGATIONS
[9] In brief, in his Basis of Claim (BOC) form, the claimant alleges that:
* He is a devout Coptic Christian from Menia, Egypt.
* He suffered from discrimination because of his religion through-out his life.
* In XXXX 2017 he lost friends in the terrorist attack on Christians who were taking a bus to a monastery.
* In XXXX 2018 his wife and daughter were attacked physically while walking in the streets after attending church.
* In XXXX 2019 he was attacked physically after he XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. He had to go to hospital to seek treatment for the injuries he sustained.
* Through the help of an agent he was able to exit Egypt. He arrived in Canada on XXXX XXXX 2019 and made a claim for refugee protection inland on or about 27 August 2019.
* He fears harm because of his religion should he return to Egypt.
DETERMINATION
[10] I find that claimant is a Convention refugee.
ANALYSIS
Personal Identity
[11] I am satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that the claimant has established his personal identity as an Egyptian citizen based on a certified true copy of his genuine Egyptian passport, tendered into evidence at Exhibit 1.
Credibility
[12] I accept the claimant's credibility. The claimant has declared that the information provided in his BOC is complete, true, and correct. The claimant's evidence is not internally inconsistent, inherently implausible or contradicted by documentary evidence on country conditions in Egypt.
[13] In assessing the claimant's credibility, the panel reviewed his BOC (Exhibit 2) and Port of Entry (POE) intake forms (Exhibit 1), as well as the claimant-specific documents tendered into evidence (Exhibit 4) by counsel including copies of:
* Egyptian National ID card
* Copy of birth enrollment
* Extract of marriage registration
* Birth certificates for the claimant's wife and three children
* Medical report
* Baptism certificates for the claimant, his wife and three children
* Letter from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX at XXXX XXXX in Egypt
* Letter from XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX in Mississauga, Ontario
* Photos of claimant in various church activities
Nexus - Reason for harm
[14] I find that the claimant has established a nexus to the Convention refugee definition, namely, his religion.
Harm Feared
[15] I find that the claimant has established that the harm feared (i.e. physical harm, discrimination amounting to persecution and/or the inability to openly or freely practice his religion without fear) is serious harm.
Agent of Harm
[16] I find that the agents of harm are radical Islamists and Egyptian society in general.
Likelihood of Harm - serious possibility
[17] I find that the claimant has established that he has a serious possibility of suffering serious harm should he return to Egypt due to his identity as a Coptic Christian. This finding is supported by the neutral country of origin information (COI) proffered by the Immigration and Refugee Board (the Board) in Exhibit 3. I specifically relied on the following information in coming to this finding:
[18] At item 2.1 of Exhibit 3 is the United States. Department of State. Egypt. Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2018 which, in the Executive Summary, sets out the general political and human rights situation in Egypt. It states:
According to its constitution, Egypt is a republic governed by an elected president and unicameral legislature. Presidential elections were held in March. Prior to the presidential elections, challengers to the incumbent president Abdel Fattah al-Sisi pulled out, citing personal decisions, political pressure, legal troubles, unfair competition, and in some cases they were arrested for alleged violations of candidacy prohibitions for military personnel. Domestic and international organizations expressed concern that government limitations on association, assembly, and expression severely constrained broad participation in the political process. Domestic and international observers concluded that government authorities professionally administered parliamentary elections in 2015 in accordance with the country's laws, while also expressing concern about restrictions on freedom of peaceful assembly, association, and expression and their negative effect on the political climate surrounding the elections.
Civilian authorities maintained effective control over the security forces.
Since President Sisi requested parliament to approve a state of emergency (SOE) after the April 2017 terrorist attack on Coptic churches, he has requested and parliament has ratified SOEs with one- or two-day gaps between every two SOE periods to meet the legal requirement that SOEs may only be renewed once.
Human rights issues included unlawful or arbitrary killings by the government or its agents and terrorist groups; forced disappearances; torture; arbitrary detention; harsh and life-threatening prison conditions; arbitrary arrest and detention; political prisoners; arbitrary or unlawful interference with privacy; undue restrictions on free expression, the press, and the internet, including censorship, site blocking, and criminal libel; substantial interference with the rights of peaceful assembly and freedom of association, including government control over registration and financing of nongovernmental organizations (NGOs); restrictions on political participation; use of the law to arbitrarily arrest and prosecute lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and intersex (LGBTI) persons; violence targeting LGBTI persons and members of other minority groups, and use of forced or compulsory child labor.
The government inconsistently punished or prosecuted officials who committed abuses, whether in the security services or elsewhere in government. In most cases the government did not comprehensively investigate allegations of human rights abuses, including most incidents of violence by security forces, contributing to an environment of impunity.
Attacks by terrorist organizations caused arbitrary and unlawful deprivation of life. Terrorist groups conducted deadly attacks on government, civilian, and security targets throughout the country, including places of worship. Authorities investigated terrorist attacks and prosecuted alleged perpetrators.
[19] This summary specifically notes the April 2017 terrorist attack on Coptic churches and also mentions that terrorist organizations operating in Egypt conducted deadly attacks in 2018 in Egypt, including targeted attacks on places of worship.
[20] At item 12.1 of Exhibit 3, the International Religious Freedom Report for 2018 for Egypt (published on 21 June 2019) discusses the current level of religious tolerance in Egypt. The report indicates that lethal violence connected with religion continued. Non-state actors continue to perpetrate discrimination and violence against Christians. Specifically, with respect to Christians it states:
On November 2, armed assailants attacked three buses carrying Christian pilgrims
to a monastery in Minya in Upper Egypt, killing seven and wounding 19. Attacks
continued on Christians and Christian-owned property, as well as on churches in
the Upper Egypt region. On May 26, seven Christians were injured in the village
of Shoqaf while attempting to defend a church from an attack by Muslim villagers.
Reports of anti-Semitic remarks on state-owned media, as well as sectarian and
defamatory speech against minority religious groups, continued during the year.
Al-Azhar, the country's primary institution for spreading Islam and defending
Islamic doctrine, held conferences on interfaith dialogue, and gave statements
condemning extremism and supporting improved relations between Muslims and
Christians
[21] At item 1.4 of Exhibit 3 is Australian government's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) Country Information Report Egypt, published on 17 June 2019. This report speaks to the recent terrorist attacks on Christians and also provides a general summary on the history and current situation of Christians in Egypt:
Terrorist Attacks on Christians
3.21 In December 2016, a suicide bomber targeted a church service at a chapel adjoining St Mark's Cathedral in Cairo, killing 29 and injuring 49. Following the previously mentioned February 2017 attacks in el Arish, IS claimed responsibility for two major attacks against Palm Sunday church services on 9 April 2017. The first attack occurred at a service in Tanta, killing 27 people and injuring over 70. The second attack occurred at a cathedral in Alexandria. At least 16 people were killed and 66 people were injured in the Alexandria attack: Pope Tawadros was saying mass at the cathedral at the time, but escaped unharmed. In May 2017 in Minya, a gunman opened fire on a bus and killed 29 people who refused to renounce their faith. In November 2018, militants ambushed three buses carrying Christian pilgrims to a remote desert monastery south of Cairo, killing seven and wounding 19. In addition to these attacks, security services have reportedly thwarted a number of attempted attacks.
Christians
3.31 Christianity was established in Egypt in the first century and is one of the oldest centres of Christianity in the world. Although there are twelve officially recognised Christian denominations in Egypt (four Orthodox, seven Catholic and one Protestant), the vast majority of Christians in Egypt are members of the Coptic Orthodox Church. All those belonging to recognised Christian denominations are identified as Christian on their national ID cards. While Christians reside throughout the country, they are particularly concentrated in Upper Egypt (the southern part of Egypt) and in major cities such as Cairo and Alexandria. Suburbs in Cairo and other cities and some villages are sometimes regarded or described as 'Christian areas', but few are exclusively Christian (or Muslim). Egyptian Christians are politically and socio-economically diverse: they hold varied professions; range from the very poor to the very rich; and have attained a range of education levels.
3.32 Christians generally dress similarly to Muslim Egyptians. In urban areas, however, Christian women are more likely than Muslim women to leave their hair uncovered. Christian women living in rural or conservative areas are more likely to cover their hair, but generally do not wear the Islamic hijab. Christians tend to have identifiable names. Some Christians tattoo small crosses on the inside of their wrists or between their thumb and forefinger as a mark of their identity, often following visits to monasteries or holy sites. Not all Christians have these tattoos and it is not a mandatory religious practice.
3.33 There are no legal barriers to prevent Christians from being visible in public life, and a number of Christians have become prominent and influential in Egyptian politics and business. DFAT understands that the percentage of Christians in the Egyptian civil service is broadly representative of the religious breakdown of the population. However, Christians tend to be under-represented in senior civil servant roles, and in the upper ranks of the military and security services. It is very rare for Christians to be appointed as presidents, deans or vice-deans in public universities. While anti-discriminatory laws and legal protections exist, these are not always enforced fairly and Christians may experience some discrimination, particularly in rural areas.
3.34 Most Christians viewed the post-2011 Revolution ascendency of the Muslim Brotherhood with considerable apprehension. They regarded the Morsi government's removal and the restoration of general law and order as a cause for relief, and strongly supported the ascendency of Sisi to the presidency. Many Christians and representatives of other minority faiths report that while things could always improve, they generally consider themselves better protected under President Sisi than previous Egyptian leaders. Christian religious authorities have consistently expressed appreciation for Sisi's public messaging which has called upon Egyptians to place national unity above religious differences, and for his personal example: in 2015, Sisi became the first Egyptian head of state to attend Christmas mass at the St. Mark's Cathedral in Cairo and has attended every year since. Sisi has actively engaged with the Christian community, declaring days of national mourning or calling personally on Pope Tawadros to express his condolences following DFAT Country Information Report Egypt 21 terrorist attacks against Christians (see Security Situation). Local sources report that Christians generally remain strong supporters of Sisi, although (like other Egyptians) their initial enthusiasm has waned due to the lack of economic improvement and ongoing social difficulties in Egypt.
...
3.36 DFAT assesses that Christians face a moderate risk of discrimination that is more likely to be societal than official in nature, and is likely to vary considerably according to geographic location. Christians, particularly in rural areas, may face difficulty in obtaining justice through legal means (see Judiciary). Despite the lack of any official policy of discrimination, Christians remain less likely than Muslims to be able to achieve senior positions in institutions such as the civil service, military and security services, and universities.
[22] Further, at item 2. 4 in Exhibit 3, is a recent report entitled Freedom House 2019 which, with respect to freedom of religion in Egypt, states:
While Article 2 of the 2014 constitution declares Islam to be the official religion of the state, Article 64 states that "freedom of belief is absolute." Most Egyptians are Sunni Muslims. Coptic Christians form a substantial minority, and there are smaller numbers of Shiite Muslims, non-Coptic Christian denominations, and other groups. Religious minorities and atheists have faced persecution and violence, with Copts in particular suffering numerous cases of forced displacement, physical assaults, bomb and arson attacks, and blocking of church construction in
recent years.
[23] At 12.6 of Exhibit 3 is a report published in April 2019 entitled: Egypt. United States Commission on International Religious Freedom, Annual Report 2019. In its "Key Findings" it reports that during 2018 religious freedom conditions in Egypt generally trended in a more positive direction with respect to high-level official discourse and actions. However, it goes on to state:
Nevertheless, despite these prominent gestures, systematic and ongoing challenges to religious freedom remained widespread at the community level, particularly in rural areas. Anti-Christian mob violence occurred with impunity and regularity in Upper Egypt; on several occasions, these incidents came in direct response to efforts by local Christians to legally register their churches. Meanwhile, Egyptian affiliates of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and domestic terror groups
continued to target local Christians in addition to government officials and security forces. Baha'is and Jehovah's Witnesses remained unrecognized, and blasphemy laws, which have not been repealed, continued to be used in targeting Muslims,
Christians, and nonreligious persons.
[24] The same document goes on to report that:
Sectarian Attacks and Legal Impunity
While incidents of violence directly targeting Christians resulted in fewer casualties than in previous years, they persisted in various forms throughout 2018. Nongovernmental interlocutors informed USCIRF during a January 2019 country visit that there were at least 25 incidents of violence or attempted violence against Christians during the reporting period. Such incidents included an attempted suicide bombing on a Coptic Orthodox church in Qalyubiya in August, which police successfully thwarted before the would-be bomber reached his intended target. In November 2018, in the deadliest single attack of the year, gunmen in the governorate of Minya attacked two minibuses of Christian pilgrims who had just left the Monastery of St. Samuel the Confessor, killing seven people and injuring seven others. The Egyptian branch of ISIS later claimed responsibility for that attack.
Egyptian authorities typically single out these large-scale incidents as symptomatic of terrorist organizations that target Christians as well as security forces and police. During 2018, ISIS and remnants of other radical Islamist groups continued to pose a serious threat to Egypt's large Christian population. However, blaming Egypt's sectarian issues on radical Islamist groups belies the reality that societal bigotry and government negligence also play roles in incidents of communal violence. Perceived negligence on the part of Egyptian security forces continued to be an ongoing grievance of the Christian population: for example, at the funeral for victims of the monastery bus attack in November, eyewitnesses reported a palpable and audible sense of anger toward police who failed to prevent the attack, despite its occurrence at a venue just one kilometer from a nearly identical and even deadlier attack on the same road in 2017. In addition, police officers are sometimes directly involved in such violence: for example, a Christian barber in Beni Suef died in police custody in July 2018 after reportedly receiving a fatal beating from officers when he attempted to report a dispute with a Muslim fellow resident. In another example, a police sergeant tasked with guarding a church in Minya gunned down a Coptic father and son at a worksite in front of his post in December, following a minor dispute. That officer was subsequently found guilty of murder charges in February 2019, after the reporting period.
The prevalence of violence against Christians in Egypt was most clearly on display in incidents of mob violence that occurred in rural towns and villages in Upper Egypt; the perpetrators were moved to action by the words of their local imams and their own deeply rooted prejudices. There were at least eight such mob attacks in 2018: in three separate attacks in August alone, Muslim rioters attacked Coptic churches, homes, and businesses in Sultan Basha, Minya; Esna, Luxor; and Dimshaw Hashim, Minya, after reports circulated that local Christians had attempted to legally register their places of worship. Although none of these attacks resulted in outright fatalities, they caused significant property destruction and terrified local Christians. Furthermore, none of them produced legal consequences for the perpetrators; instead, by deferring to customary reconciliation sessions, local authorities made concessions to the rioters by agreeing to close the churches or prayer halls in dispute.
Apart from more overt examples of direct violence, Coptic Christians continued to face widespread societal pressures such as religious discrimination and outright bigotry.
[25] I find that the neutral COI evidence supports the claimant's allegations that, despite the level of overall harm against Coptic Christians dropping recently in Egypt, he has a serious possibility of suffering serious harm should he return to Egypt due to his identity as a Coptic Christian man from El Mania. The COI reports that societal discrimination against Christians exists and sometimes Coptic Christians are victims of appalling violence at the hands of Muslim extremists. Given his past personal experiences of physical harm at the hands of religious extremists and the neutral country conditions, the claimant has established that he has a serious possibility of meeting with similar harm in the future because of his religious identity should he return to Egypt.
State Protection
[26] I find that the claimant has established on a balance of probabilities that adequate state protection is not available to him.
[27] In the case at bar, the claimant does not mention ever attempting to seek police protection for any reason. In his BOC the claimant stated that: "the authorities in Egypt are not interested in intervening in religious disputes."
[28] With respect to the issue of state protection, the panel considered all of the previously cited evidence and in particular notes the information at item 12.6 of Exhibit 3 which states: "... blaming Egypt's sectarian issues on radical Islamist groups belies the reality that societal bigotry and government negligence also play roles in incidents of communal violence."
[29] I have carefully reviewed the documentary evidence filed by the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) and find that this particular claimant, given his circumstances has provided clear and convincing evidence that he would be unable to avail himself of adequate state protection. While Egypt has made improvements in protecting Christians and their right to practice their religion, I find that those improvements have not translated in operationally effective adequate protection for this particular claimant at this point in time. I find that the claimant has overcome the presumption of state protection.
Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
[30] I find that there is no viable IFA for this claimant in Egypt.
[31] The claimant alleges that there is nowhere in Egypt that he could live safely without enduring persistent societal discrimination or the threat of violence. In his BOC he states that: "I fear Muslim extremists and as Muslim extremists exist throughout Egypt there is no place in Egypt where I can seek safety." The neutral COI suggests that Christians from rural areas in Upper Egypt face a greater likelihood of violence. However, at item 12.6 of Exhibit 3 (cited above) it also states: "Apart from more overt examples of direct violence, Coptic Christians continued to face widespread societal pressures such as religious discrimination and outright bigotry." Given all of the evidence produced in this case, the panel accepts the claimant's allegations with respect to a lack of a viable IFA.
CONCLUSION
[32] I determine that the claimant is a Convention refugee pursuant to section 96 of the IRPA and therefore allows his claim.
(signed)
"L. Figg"
L. Figg
2 January 2020
Date
1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27, as amended, sections 96 and 97(1).
2 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27, as amended, section 170(f).
3 Refugee Protection Division Rules (SOR/2012-256).
4 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27, as amended, section 162(2).

APPLICATION TO REINSTATE CLAIMS
[1] This is a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) in the applications of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXand XXXX XXXX (applicants) to reinstate their refugee claims. The applicants are a family comprised of a mother (Rajni RAJPUT) (adult applicant), and her two minor children, Anirudra RAJPUT, and Ayush RAJPUT). The applicants have not been represented by counsel in their refugee claims or their application to reinstate their claims.
[2] The applicants' refugee claims were referred to the RPD on June 20, 2019. The applicants are citizens of India who claim to fear the local police as the police harassed, attacked, and arrested the adult applicant and other members of her husband's family.
[3] The adult applicant provided a Notice of Withdrawal of a Claim for Refugee Protection to the RPD which was signed on XXXX XXXX XXXX 2019. The RPD confirmed the withdrawal of the claims on XXXX XXXX XXXX 2019. The applicants applied to reinstate their claims on XXXX XXXX XXXX 2019. The applicants submitted additional materials on XXXX XXXX XXXX 2019 and XXXX XXXX XXXX 2019 which include submissions, an affidavit from the adult applicant's brother, and a medical report of XXXX XXXX XXXX. The Minister's Counsel confirmed on December 10, 2019 that she does not take a position on this application.
[4] The adult claimant explained in her application that she requested to withdraw the claim because her brother told her that he could help her settle her problems with the local police in India. The adult claimant applicant stated that she later learned from her brother that the police were not willing to settle their issues with the applicant, and they were demanding a significant sum of money from her family in order to settle the problem.
[5] Rule 60 of the RPD Rules1 provides that a person may make an application to the Division to reinstate a claim that was made by the person and was withdrawn.
[6] RPD Rule 60 further states as follows:
3) The Division must not allow the application unless it is established that there was a failure to observe a principle of natural justice or it is otherwise in the interests of justice to allow the application.
(4) In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including whether the application was made in a timely manner and the justification for any delay.
[7] The adult applicant did not state in the application when her brother informed her that the police demanded a large sum of money from her family in order to settle their differences. However, the application to reinstate was made within about two weeks of the applicants' withdrawal of their refugee claims. There does not appear to be a delay in making this application.
[8] There is no breach of natural justice alleged by the applicants. The applicants appear to be making an application to reinstate their claims because their circumstances have changed. At the time the adult applicant withdrew these claims, she made a strategic decision based on her brother's information that he could settle her problems with the local police. She has since received some information from her brother to indicate that her problems with the police cannot be resolved.
[9] I find that the adult applicant's symptoms of XXXXand XXXX described in a letter from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX do not demonstrate that the adult applicant's decision to withdraw from the claim was made due to duress, lack of information or a mistake. She made the decision to withdraw the refugee claims, her decision was made based on her information she received from her brother about the situation in India. It is not alleged that the adult claimant made the decision to withdraw the claims due to XXXX XXXX XXXX, or any other XXXX disorder.
[10] The Federal Court has stated as follows in Ohanyan v. Canada (MCI), 2006 FC 1078:
The term "otherwise in the interests of justice" are word giving the Board a wide discretion to reinstate but which requires the Board to weigh all the circumstances of a case- not just from the vantage point of the applicant's interests. Reinstatement is an exception to the norm and must be interpreted in that context.
[11] The applicants are not represented by counsel and they have not made submissions about whether there are interests of injustice that weigh in favour of reinstating these claims. Based on the evidence before me, the adult applicant has simply changed her mind about her decision about whether these claims should be withdrawn. She made a strategic decision which may not have worked out to her advantage. Reinstatement is an exception to the norm. I find that it is not otherwise in the interests of justice to reinstate these claims. Accordingly, I dismiss this application to reinstate the claims.
(signed)
"Becky Chan"
Becky Chan
January 31, 2020
Date

REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX (the "principal claimant"), his wife XXXX XXXX (the "associate claimant") and their four children XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX (the "minor claimants"), claim to be citizens of Pakistan and seek refugee protection pursuant to Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
[2] The associate claimant was appointed as designated representative for the minor claimants. The panel heard these claims jointly pursuant to RPD Rule 55.
[3] The claim was started by a member who heard evidence in one hearing but was unable to conclude the case for administrative reasons. As a result, the claim was subject to a re-hearing that was heard in two sittings. The second panel considered the same evidence, but did not consider the testimony at the first proceeding. However, the panel would note that there was no reason for this beyond expediency, and no finding of a failure of natural justice or similar concern was alleged or found.
ALLEGATIONS
[4] The claimants' allegations are set out in detail in their Basis of Claim (BOC) forms.2 In summary, the claimants allege that the associate claimant (a Sunni Muslim) was tasked in her work as an XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in Lahore to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. They allege that the XXXX threatened the associate claimant to stop her XXXX and indicated that he had links to a Sunni extremist group called Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat. They further allege that the associate claimant and then the principal claimant (a Shia Muslim) received threatening phone calls from this extremist group and fear persecution from both the XXXX and Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat should they return to Pakistan.
[5] The principal claimant alleges he left Pakistan and traveled to Canada on a visitor visa on XXXX XXXX, 2018. His claim for refugee protection was referred to the Board on June 28, 2018. The associate and minor claimants left Pakistan and traveled to the United States on XXXX XXXX, 2018. On XXXX XXXX, 2018 they traveled to a Canadian port of entry where they, too, made an asylum claim.
DETERMINATION
[6] Having considered the totality of the evidence, the panel finds that the claimants are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection, for the following reasons.
ANALYSIS
[7] The determinative issue in this claim is the availability of an internal flight alternative (IFA).
[8] The panel notes that the associate claimant provided the majority of the testimony, but the principal claimant also testified during each of the two hearings where substantive evidence was taken. He testified that he agreed with the associate claimant's testimony at both hearings.
Identity
[9] The claimants' personal identities and their Pakistani citizenship have been established on a balance of probabilities through their Pakistani passports, copies of which are on file.3
[10] The claimants also established their religious identities, with the principal claimant as a Shia Muslim and the associate claimant as a Sunni Muslim, through their oral testimony and documentary evidence provided, including letters from the principal claimant's Imam Bargahs (Shia houses of worship) in Canada and Pakistan.4
Credibility
[11] The panel did not find the claimants credible regarding their allegations for a number of reasons, including that alleged Sunni extremist group Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat does not appear in the objective evidence on Pakistan. However, as the panel has found an available IFA for the claimants, and IFA is determinative, credibility will not be further addressed here.
INTERNAL FLIGHT ALTERNATIVE
[12] Even if the panel had found the allegations put forth credible and determined that the claimants face harm in Pakistan, the panel believes they have an IFA in their home country. Islamabad, Karachi and Hyderabad were identified as areas where the claimants could relocate and canvassed at the hearing, but only Hyderabad is addressed in these reasons.
[13] In determining whether an IFA exists, the panel must apply the two-prong test set out by the Federal Court of Appeal in the case of Rasaratnam.5 First, the panel must find that the claimants would be safe in Hyderabad, and secondly that it would be reasonable to expect the claimants to relocate there. Once the panel raises the issue at a hearing, the claimants bear the onus to show that there is no viable IFA for them in their home country.
No serious possibility of persecution in proposed IFA
[14] The associate claimant testified that the family would not be safe in the proposed IFA locations because Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat will find them. When asked how they would find the claimants, the principal and associate claimants testified that these groups have a strong network and their guys are in every institution in Pakistan, including at the National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA). The claimants also testified that they will be located when they try to rent a home or obtain a mobile phone.
[15] The documentary evidence on Pakistan does not contain any references to any group known as Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat. The associate claimant at the second hearing testified that the XXXX XXXX identified himself as a member of Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat when she was XXXX him, and that she had heard of this group many times and that it is talked about that this group has a big network. The panel noted at the second hearing that there is no mention of Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat in the National Documentation Package (NDP) for Pakistan and the associate claimant testified that she has heard the name popping up at home, that the XXXX XXXX mentioned this name in his XXXX, and that police and the XXXX where she worked reacted after she mentioned this name in each location.
[16] It is reasonable to expect that if there was a Sunni extremist organisation in Pakistan that targeted individuals such as the claimants and had a large network of this nature across Pakistan that it would be mentioned somewhere in the NDP. At the second hearing, after the panel noted that there was no mention of this group in the NDP, counsel provided a Research and Information Request document from the Board dated September 8, 20096 that stated the following:
"About the Barelvi and Sunni distinction among the Sunni religious groups, it should be borne in mind that the SSP is backed by the Sunni Deobandi groups. ... [T]here are two sets of similar sounding Sunni organizations: one, Tanzeem Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat; two, Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat. The names of their spellings continue to vary in English language when reported by the media, but the key distinction is of Tehreek versus Tanzeem. Sometimes, these two words are not used, thereby confusing even the innocent religious man.
However, if the word Tanzeem figures in their name, it belongs to Deobandi school and is the mother of Sunni militant organizations like the SSP. So, in this case, Tanzeem Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat, a coalition of Deobandi organizations, is the mother of the SSP. Its alternative spelling is also Ahlay Sunnat Al-Jammat Pakistan. On the other hand, the Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat is a coalition of Barelvi groups of Sunni organizations. These are soft-natured, but nevertheless extremely orthodox. (Sometimes, even softer versions of these groups undergo political transformation; for example, Sunni Tehreek, a Barelvi organization, has been transformed into a political group and is now involved in violence in Pakistani city of Karachi.)"7
[17] The panel notes that the claimants allege fear of persecution by a group identified as "Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat", and this document references a group called "Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat", and thus that the names are similar but not the same. The document provided by counsel indicates the spellings of group names may vary when reported in English; there is no indication that the names may change by losing whole words. The panel further notes that the document indicates that the group "Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat" is identified as backing Sunni extremist group "SSP", or Sipah-e-Sahaba Pakistan, and also is a "soft-natured, but nevertheless extremely orthodox" group. The document does not contain any information as to the activities of Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat; this document is also more than ten years old as of the final hearing in this claim and thus its relevance is further diminished in this claim.
[18] Moreover, there is also no mention of a group called Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat in the present objective evidence for Pakistan. And despite providing numerous country condition documents in support of their claim in Exhibits 5, 6, 7 and 9, the claimants provided no other documentary evidence as to the existence or profile of any group called Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat or Tehreek Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat. The panel thus finds the claimants have not established that the Sunni extremist group they allege to fear in Pakistan even exists. The claimants therefore failed to establish that the XXXX XXXX belongs to any Sunni extremist group, or that he would pose any risk to the claimants in the IFA location otherwise.
[19] However, even if there is a group called Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat, and it has links with SSP, the claimants have put forward no persuasive evidence that SSP are aware of their existence, that anyone has shared the claimants' information with them or that there is any precedent for them doing so given their status within Pakistan. Although there is evidence of links between SSP and other sectarian groups,8 documentary sources also confirm the fractious nature of the various militant groups operating in Pakistan.9
[20] Moreover, even had the claimants come to the attention of SSP via a group called Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat, while the SSP operates in different parts of the country its dominance is not everywhere. The documentary evidence indicates that the SSP was created in central Punjab province with a sectarian, anti-Shia agenda and has been carrying out attacks against Shia since 1985. It now operates under the name Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ).10 Its operations consist of core membership in the several hundred at most supported by a network of loosely coordinated cells of sympathisers across the country.11 Other sources reveal that militant groups have attacked Shias primarily in Quetta, Kuran, Gilgit Baltistan, Dera Ismail Khan, Parachinar, Hangu and parts of Karachi.12 The documentary evidence does not indicate that Hyderabad is a city controlled by the SSP, or that an individual would be targeted there if they are not a high profile person. These documents make reference to sectarian groups attacking Shia processions and religious gatherings by bombing, including suicide bombing, and drive-by shootings. However personal targeting in these blasts is not something that features prominently in the documentary evidence.
[21] In addition, though the SSP is known to have a capacity to strike throughout the country, the evidence does not suggest that this capacity extends beyond indiscriminate "mass casualty" attacks against a community at large (e.g., procession, public gathering or mosque) or the specific targeting of high-profile individuals such as prominent leaders. This evidence is insufficient to conclude the SSP are active in personally targeting individuals with profiles like the claimants who have relocated to places like the proposed city (far removed from areas affected by sustained security and military counterinsurgency operations and retaliatory militant attacks and known to be relatively free from terrorist and sectarian violence).13
[22] The claimants are not high profile. The associate claimant held an XXXX position at a XXXX and the principal claimant was unemployed at the time of their alleged problems in Pakistan.
[23] The claimants also allege that they will be located as a result of having to rent accommodation or obtain a mobile phone. There is information before the panel supporting the existence of situations where individuals in Pakistan are required to provide identification to state authorities. For instance, identification is required for those seeking to rent premises to live. A tenant registration system exists in all four provinces in Pakistan.14 However, the purpose for this system is information-gathering, to track the movement of people involved in criminal activities.15 There was no evidence before the panel to suggest that the claimants are involved in criminal activities or that the police in Pakistan have any interest in them. To this end, the claimants all have Pakistani exit stamps in their passports for XXXX XXXX, 2018,16 and there is no persuasive evidence that the claimants had any issues with authorities at the airport in Islamabad while exiting.
[24] The documentary evidence states the police might communicate with the authorities in different provinces to find persons of interest, and that "this usually takes place in high profile cases and not just any case" because "the police authorities only tend to do so if absolutely necessary."17
[25] While there is some indication that militant groups have links with law enforcement in Pakistan, it is speculative to assume that the SSP would seek and obtain assistance from the police to locate the claimants, who are not high-profile individuals. Although the documentary evidence states that "reporting the threats to the police could make the victim more vulnerable" given that "[s]ome police have anti-Shia sentiments and it is hard to know whether the police will act as a friend"18 this was not the claimants' experience. The claimants stated in their BOCs and oral testimony that they contacted police in Pakistan after allegedly receiving threatening phone calls on XXXX XXXX, 2018 and XXXX XXXX, 2018, and that they reported an alleged threat to police in XXXX 2018 in which the police refused to register a First Information Report but did register the claimants' complaint. Though the police allegedly did not respond to the degree desired by the claimants, there is no persuasive evidence that the police behaved in an anti-Shia manner towards them.
[26] No other persuasive evidence was provided to establish that police were in any way in cahoots with or under the control of the SSP in seeking to harm the claimants. Thus, the panel finds that the claimants failed to establish that in their particular circumstances, there were any SSP links with local police in Lahore, or that if there were, that this would result in any increased risk to them in the IFA location of Hyderabad.
[27] The panel also notes that the objective evidence for Pakistan does not substantiate the associate claimant's allegations that they would be located in Hyderabad as a result of obtaining new SIM cards, for which they would have to show their identity documents. The panel has found that there is no indication the police have taken any interest in the claimants; there is also no persuasive evidence before the panel that extremist groups on their own would be able to access and monitor such information. As such, the panel finds these concerns speculative and not supported by the objective evidence.
[28] The panel further notes the claimants allege they fled their home in Lahore, relocating to the home of a friend in Islamabad on XXXX XXXX, 2018 before leaving Pakistan on XXXX XXXX and XXXX, 2018.19 The claimants state in their BOCs that on XXXX XXXX, 2018, the associate claimant received a phone call on her recently changed cell phone number, and that the "caller said that she could not hide and that the time was over, so the family should now be ready to face the consequences" and then hung up.20 At the first hearing, the associate claimant testified that while the claimants were in Islamabad when nobody knew their address or phone number 'they' were able to locate us. At the second hearing, the associate claimant testified that she provided her new cell phone number to the XXXX where she worked, and that the caller did not say anything additional during this call. The associate claimant further testified that there were no incidents in Islamabad after this alleged threatening phone call. The panel finds there is no persuasive evidence that the claimants were in fact located by anyone while in Islamabad, rather than, for example, the caller correctly guessing that the claimants had abandoned their family home in Lahore. The panel finds that the alleged threatening phone call on XXXX XXXX, 2018, does not itself indicate any ability on the part of the alleged agents of persecution to locate the claimants in the IFA location.
[29] The panel has found that the claimants failed to establish that Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat exists. As such, this group could not have given the claimants' information to SSP. However, even assuming without finding that the claimants had come to the attention of SSP, the panel finds on a balance of probabilities that should the claimants relocate to Hyderabad, the possibility of the claimants being tracked by the SSP is remote. Notably, the documentary evidence indicates that "[w]here the person's fear is of persecution and/or serious harm at the hands of non-state actors, in general they will be able to relocate to escape that risk."21
[30] The proposed IFA of Hyderabad is almost 1,100 kilometres away from the claimants' family home in Lahore and the problems they allegedly faced there. Pakistan is a country with an area of approximately 800,000 square kilometres and a population of more than 200 million.22 All of this provides a significant degree of anonymity for the claimants and greatly reduces the likelihood of the claimants being located in the proposed IFAs.
[31] Given all of the above, the panel finds that the claimants have not established they would face a serious possibility of harm in Hyderabad.
The second prong - reasonable in all the circumstances
[32] In considering whether it would be objectively unreasonable or unduly harsh for the claimants to relocate to Hyderabad, the panel is reminded that the Federal Court of Appeal has set out a very high threshold for this test.23
[33] Other than the fear of being located by the agents of persecution, the claimants did not put forth reasons why they could not relocate to Hyderabad, a large city with more than one million residents. Hyderabad has a multi-ethnic population, with people speaking many languages. The claimants speak Urdu, the official language of Pakistan, and some English, another official language in Pakistan that is described as the lingua franca of the Pakistani elite and most government ministries.24 Urdu and English are spoken all over the country, including in Hyderabad.25
[34] There was no evidence put forth that the claimants would not be able to physically travel to the proposed IFA. The claimants are citizens of Pakistan and have freedom of internal movement throughout the country.26 The panel notes that the claimants have prior experience relocating to places unfamiliar to them, including XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the XXXX XXXX and Canada, but adjusted to their circumstances. The claimants should have little difficulty adjusting in Hyderabad, which is more familiar to them.
[35] The principal claimant has XXXX XXXX of education27 and numerous years of work experience, both in Pakistan and abroad. The associate claimant has XXXX XXXX of education and recent work experience in Pakistan. The claimants likewise have the support of their family and religious communities in Pakistan.
[36] Pakistan has a population of 207.8 million people, with an estimated Shia Muslim population of between 10% and 25% of that total.28 While the panel acknowledges that Shias continue to face problems in Pakistan, the evidence seems to suggest that millions do live in relative safety, and given the fact that "Shi'a mosques are located throughout Pakistan, including in major cities and towns,"29 the majority are arguably able to practice their faith freely. Furthermore, there is no persuasive evidence that the principal claimant faced any serious issues in the years he lived as a practicing Shia in Pakistan before the problems he allegedly faced with Tehrik Ahle-e-Sunnat. There is no indication that the problems the claimants allegedly face go beyond localized issues in Lahore.
[37] The panel finds on a balance of probabilities that the principal claimant will be able to freely practice his Shia faith upon return to Pakistan, including participating in Shia activities in Hyderabad as desired.
[38] In light of the above, the panel finds on a balance of probabilities that there are no serious social, economic, language, religious or other barriers to the claimants relocating in Hyderabad. The panel therefore finds that it would not be unreasonable, in all circumstances, including those particular to the claimants, for them to seek refuge in Hyderabad.
CONCLUSION
[39] The panel finds the claimants have a viable IFA in Pakistan. Given that IFA is determinative of both Section 96 and Section 97, the panel finds the claimants are not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection.
[40] The panel rejects the claims pursuant to both sections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA.

REASONS FOR DECISION
INTRODUCTION
[1] This is the decision in the claims of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, citizens of Colombia, who are claiming refugee protection pursuant to ss. 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
[2] The claimants allege that they have a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of their imputed political opinion, specifically their imputed opposition to the group known as the National Liberation Army or "ELN".
[3] The adult claimant gave the bulk of the testimony and served as Designated Representative for the minor claimant.
[4] The claimants fled to the United States in XXXX 2018 but did not make asylum claims there. They came on to Canada and claimed refugee status here.
DETERMINATION
[5] I find that the claimants have not established that they are Convention Refugees nor persons in need of protection under ss. 96 or 97 of the IRPA.
[6] I make this finding based on the conclusion that the claimants have a viable internal flight alternative ("IFA") in Medellin.
ANALYSIS
Identity -The Claimants' Identities as Citizens of Colombia
[7] The claimants' identities as citizens of Colombia was established by certified copies of the claimants' Colombian passports and the claimants' testimony. On this basis I am satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that they are citizens of Colombia.
EVENTS GIVING RISE TO THE CLAIM
[8] The agents of persecution in this case are members of the ELN.
[9] The alleged events may be summarized as follows:
[10] The events in question center around a farm about XXXX XXXX to XXXX XXXX outside of Baranquilla, closer to Sabanalarga. Further testimony revealed that the farm is about two hours from XXXX XXXX. In sum, the farm is in the northern part of Colombia.
[11] The farm is not owned by the claimants. The farm in question was (and as far as is known, still is) owned by the ex-husband of the adult claimant (or simply "the ex-husband").
[12] The claimants were near this farm on or about XXXX 2018. They were approached by armed men who took hold of the minor claimant, saying that they were ELN members and wanted to recruit the minor claimant. The adult claimant screamed; the minor claimant struggled free. The armed men said that what they really wanted was the ex-husband's farm. The armed men took some money, and the claimants were allowed to go.
[13] When describing the demands of these armed men in testimony, the adult claimant clarified that they seemed to want the use of the land, not legal title (judging from what was said). She had no idea why they wanted the land.
[14] In XXXX of 2018, the claimants moved to Bogota. The adult claimant had a sister there, and besides, she needed medical treatment.
[15] In XXXX 2018, still in Bogota, the minor claimant was threatened with a knife by some unknown men. They said that even in Bogota the claimants could not escape. The claimants assumed that these men were also members of the ELN.
[16] In XXXX 2018, immediately after the threatening incident noted above, the claimants moved to XXXX in XXXX. Nothing significant happened there.
[17] In XXXX 2018, the claimants moved back to Bogota. The adult claimant needed further medical treatment, and the ex-husband needed witnesses with respect to a police report concerning the original event in February.
[18] In XXXX 2018, in Bogota, the minor claimant saw one of the men who had threatened him in XXXX 2018.
[19] In XXXX 2018, the claimants moved to Barranquilla, and the next day moved on to XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX is about XXXX XXXX from Barranquilla. As noted above, XXXX XXXX is about two hours distance from the farm the use of which was allegedly sought by the ELN.
[20] In XXXX 2018, the ex-husband came to where the claimants were staying in XXXX XXXX in order to visit the minor claimant. As he was arriving, four shots were fired by one of two men on a motorcycle. The bullets did not hit anyone. The police were called, and the license number of the motorcycle was provided to them.
[21] In XXXX 2018, the claimants fled to the United States and then to Canada.
[22] The claimants made no claim in the United States because they have no family there. They do have relatives in Canada - an aunt and a cousin who came a number of years ago, claimed refugee status, and were accepted on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
[23] Over a span of some months, the ex-husband received four pamphlets, allegedly from the ELN, saying that the family had been made military objectives.
CREDIBILITY
[24] The adult claimant, as noted, gave most of the testimony. She proved to be a cooperative witness. Her memory, particularly for events and places, was good. When she made an error, as she sometimes did, she usually caught it and corrected it herself without being asked. I find that she was credible as far as the events giving rise to the claim are concerned. I also find, however, that her interpretation of events, as they related to IFA, drew inferences with respect to the level of danger that she and her son would face in Colombia. Those inferences went beyond what the evidence would support and in short, she is embellishing her case.
OBSERVATIONS CONCERNING EVENTS
[25] The account given above shows that the claimants experienced a good deal of movement in 2018. The claimants were threatened near the farm (which is the center of the dispute and which is XXXX XXXX to XXXX XXXX from Barranquilla, in the northern part of the country) and the son was threatened in Bogota.
[26] Other locations were noted. When they were in XXXX XXXX, in XXXX, shots were fired at the ex-husband. The claimants had no trouble in XXXX in XXXX.
INTERNAL FLIGHT ALTERNATIVE (IFA)
[27] To find a viable IFA, the panel must be satisfied that (1) there is no serious possibility of the claimants being persecuted or, on the balance of probabilities, in danger of torture or subjected to a risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in the IFA; and (2) that conditions in that part of the country are such that it would be reasonable, in all the circumstances, including those particular to the claimants, for them to seek refuge there. (Rasaratnam v. Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration), [1992] 1 F.C. 706 (C.A.))
(1) Risk in the IFA?
[28] On the evidence, is there a serious possibility of the claimant being persecuted or, on the balance of probabilities, of being in danger of torture or at risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in the proposed IFA?
(2) Is It Reasonable for the Claimant to Re-Locate to the Proposed IFA?
[29] With respect to the burden of proof, in Rasaratnam, the Court of Appeal held that once IFA is raised as an issue, the onus is on the claimant to show that he or she does not have an IFA. The burden placed on the claimant is fairly high in order to show that the IFA is unreasonable. The Federal Court of Appeal in this case stated that the test to show that the IFA is unreasonable requires nothing less than the existence of conditions that would jeopardize the life and safety of the claimant in relocating to a safe place. Actual and concrete evidence of adverse conditions is required.
[30] As noted, I find that the claimants have an IFA in the proposed location of Medellin.
Lack of Risk in the Proposed IFA
[31] To avoid confusion if someone is reviewing the record, I note that two IFA locations were proposed. For the purposes of this decision, I am focusing on Medellin.
[32] The adult claimant was asked whether she and her son would be safe in Medellin, and she answered in the negative. Her response was to the effect that not only her ex-husband but his family, with the adult and minor claimants included, had been declared military targets by the ELN. She explained that military targets were people that the ELN were going to assassinate, confront or bother. She testified that she had no idea of how many people had been declared to be military targets in this way.
[33] She also pointed out that Medellin is not as big as Bogota. Her son, the minor claimant, was located by the ELN when they moved to Bogota. She reasoned that if the ELN could find the claimants in Bogota, then surely, they could find her and her son in a smaller city like Medellin.
[34] The adult claimant noted that the ELN was operating in the province in which Medellin is located, and in fact was operative in all the provinces in Colombia. What is more, according to the claimants the ELN has made alliances with FARC.
[35] The motive that the ELN would have to track the claimants down would be that indicated above: The ex-husband has not transferred to the ELN the use of some farmland as they wanted him to do.
[36] I do not accept this response because I find that the claimants have not demonstrated that the ELN has the motive or the means to have instituted an ongoing, country-wide search for the claimants.
[37] I make this finding for a number of reasons. First of all, the claimants do not appear to be the primary targets. The ex-husband is the person who has not transferred the use of the land to the ELN, and thereby incurred their anger. True, the claimants have been told - second-hand - that they have been made "military targets", but that declaration still flows from the apparent desire of the ELN to obtain control of the ex-husband's farmland. In all of this, we have not learned why the ELN wants to use the land at all.
[38] According to our most recent documentation on the subject, information about the ELN's ability to track people is scarce.2 This is directly contrary to the objective information like other groups in Colombia like FARC which, incidentally, essentially demobilized in 2017. The comparative dearth of information substantiating any ability of the ELN to track victims is likely because the ELN is highly decentralized,3 a fact to which the adult claimant alluded in testimony. It is possible that the ELN could track someone down, but more likely than not that this effort would be for people with a higher profile, who have provoked the ELN beyond simply having had the misfortune to be family members of someone who has not complied with their demands.
[39] The claimants' personal history is, of course, critical. They have been threatened in the vicinity of the farm the use of which is the source of all of this trouble. The minor claimant has also been threatened in Bogota. I accept as reasonable the adult claimant's assumption that the party who threatened him in Bogota was a member of the ELN. It would be pointless for me to speculate as to how the claimants were found by the ELN in Bogota; I have no idea how the minor claimant was located by the ELN in Bogota, and neither do the claimants. Indeed, that is the point. Without any sound idea of how the minor claimant was located in Bogota, any argument drawing from this history an inference that he could be found again elsewhere would be speculative. The discovery of the claimants' location in Bogota could have been drawn from a specific occurrence - or not; we simply don't know. Getting down to the specific proposed IFA location of Medellin, I note the adult claimant's argument to the effect that Bogota is larger. In that, she is right. According to our documents, Bogota had a population of 10.574 million in 2018, while Medellin had a population of only 3.934 million in the same year4. What I do not accept is the adult claimant's argument to the effect that this observation supports the idea that Medellin would not do as an IFA location. As noted above, the fact that the ELN members threatened the younger claimant in Bogota is unexplained. A large city like Medellin - and a population of 3.934 million does arguably qualify Medellin as a large city - still presents a large urban centre in which the prospect of being located by an armed extremist group - in the case of the ELN, an armed extremist group that seems to focus most of its attacks in the countryside5 - has not, in my view, been established by the evidence before me.
[40] It is up to the claimants in each case to establish, on a balance of probabilities, that a given IFA location would not be viable. Reviewing the evidence above, I find that the claimants have not established, on a balance of probabilities, that the proposed IFA location of Medellin would not be safe from the agents of persecution - in this case, the ELN.
Second part of the IFA test.
[41] The claimants were given an opportunity to speak to the issue of whether it would be reasonable for them to live in Medellin, aside from the alleged fear of the ELN.
[42] The adult claimant raised a number of points, most notably associated with her profession and her health.
[43] The adult claimant explained that she has worked for many years in the XXXX XXXX industry. The has specialized knowledge XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. For her to start again in another area would be, as it is agued, an unreasonable hardship.
[44] The courts have noted that there is always hardship in relocation. The test in this aspect of an IFA is always high. The adult claimant presented herself in the hearing as an experienced and confident person. On a balance of probabilities, I find it that she has not established that she would face unreasonable difficulties in making a successful new start in another part of Colombia - in XXXX XXXX or another area.
[45] The adult claimant's argument that she has health issues - mainly stress-related -- that would negate any chance of relocation also does not convince. Relocation and, indeed, the refugee claim process does involve stress as well. Too low a threshold with respect to health-related stress would essentially eliminate the possibility of any IFA at all. In this case, I have reviewed the adult claimant's documentary evidence, and I do not question that she has health issues. What I do question is that any of these issues are such that it would be unreasonable for the adult claimant to relocate in Medellin. Again, I note that the adult claimant presented herself in the hearing as intelligent and confident. Reviewing the documents, I find that I am not convinced, on a balance of probabilities, that her health issues would give rise to unreasonable difficulties if she were to relocate in Medellin.
IFA: CONCLUSION
[46] For the reasons given above, I find that the claimants have not met the onus placed upon them with respect to the possibility of an IFA in Medellin.
[47] I find, accordingly, that the claimants have a viable IFA in Medellin, and I reject their claims.
(signed)
Robert Gould
R. Gould
