REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] The claimant, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, is a citizen of Colombia who seeks refugee protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.1
Late Disclosure
[2] Shortly after the start of the oral hearing, counsel advised the panel that he wished to tender late disclosure consisting of a single page picture or screenshot, which showed the claimant and an unidentified woman, alleged to be from YouTube and regarding the claimant's activities as an activist in Canada. However, this photo did not indicate the source, any URL, or the date taken. Also. it included only Spanish letters on a sign, with no translation.
[3] The panel asked counsel why it should accept the late disclosure. Counsel said that this came to his attention two days ago and the screenshot was actually from a Spanish language video which the claimant could show on his cell phone regarding a Facebook post. Counsel said that the video was a very short interview with the claimant, about two minutes long.
[4] The panel asked counsel if there was a transcript in English, but there was none. Counsel said that the video was only from the previous week.
[5] The panel refused the late disclosure. There was no indication of the source nor the date, and counsel made only a vague assertion regarding the relevance of the document. Counsel did not explain how the late disclosure was relevant to the claimant's fear of persecution in Colombia. Moreover, the proposed video was not accompanied with any English or French transcript translation, and therefore not compliant with RPD Rule 32.
[6] RPD Rule 36, regarding late disclosure, states that the Division must consider any relevant factors, including the document's relevance and probative value. However, counsel did not explain why the either the single page photograph tendered from the screenshot or any cell-phone video had specific relevance or probative value as evidence regarding either the claimant's alleged profile, or his fear of return to Colombia. It was also unclear whether the document brought any new evidence to the hearing, and furthermore, the photo itself only related to a video which was not in English or French.
ALLEGATIONS
[7] The claimant alleges in his Basis of Claim Narrative2 that he was threatened with death by the Urabenos, an armed group in Colombia belonging to the Gulf Clan, and the authorities cannot give him any sort of assistance. He lived in Medellin city, but believes that he cannot be safe anywhere else in the country as the nation is still controlled by several armed groups, guerillas, and paramilitaries.
[8] Starting in XXXX 2011 he volunteered at XXXX XXXX XXXX, an organization founded by his father which XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. The claimant made XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXspecifically in the XXXX and XXXX Communes in Medellin.
[9] On approximately XXXX XXXX, 2012 he received a telephone call from the Urabenos warning him not to return to the number XXXX Commune or he would be killed. However, he ignored the threat because at that time he was focusing his efforts on the other Commune. Around XXXX 2012 he was driving when he was stopped by individuals in uniforms who told him they were the Urabenos, and stole goods, money, and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. They also damaged the vehicle and one of them told the claimant that he had been warned earlier, and should listen to this final chance.
[10] The organizers at XXXX thought that the claimant's activities should cease for a time, but after a few months he restarted, in XXXX 2013. The following month the claimant was attacked by a man in uniform who informed him that he "had 6 months to leave the country, [he] would be declared 'Military Target' after this time".3
[11] The claimant decided to visit friends in Canada for a while "until some time passed".4 He obtained a Canadian visitor visa from the Embassy and left Colombia for Canada on XXXX XXXX, 2013.
[12] Time passed in Canada and he lost his status as a legal visitor, while the situation in Colombia alternated between times of peace and violence.
[13] He met a woman, XXXX, a Canadian permanent resident and she decided to sponsor him to immigrate to Canada. The relationship lasted for XXXX years, including XXXX when they were married. The claimant ignored his problems in Colombia. Sadly, the marriage floundered and she left the marital home on XXXX XXXX, 2018, following which the sponsorship application was withdrawn. The claimant received a letter from Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) requiring him to leave by September 20, 2018.
[14] The claimant was then preparing to return to Colombia and told his family, but his mother and brother warned him to stay away as the Urabenos had resurfaced that year with continued violence, and were looking for the claimant as he had been declared a Military Target whom they wished to punish.
[15] The claimant fears that the situation in Colombia is unlikely to change for the better as the armed groups continue to attack civilians, while the police are inefficient and afraid of the armed groups. Police cannot guarantee the safety of citizens like him who have become a Military Objective.
[16] An Amended Narrative5 was provided with cover letter of October 25, 2019. The amendments consisted of minor corrections to grammar and syntax from the original. It was not signed or dated.
DETERMINATION
[17] The panel Member finds that the claimant is not a Convention refugee and that the claimant has not established that, on a balance of probabilities, he would personally face a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment should he return to Colombia. His claim is rejected.
[18] Furthermore, the panel Member determines that there was no credible or trustworthy evidence on which it could have made a favourable decision, and finds that there is no credible basis for the claim pursuant to subsection 107(2) of the IRPA.
[19] The determinative issue is the claimant's credibility.
IDENTITY
[20] The panel accepts that the claimant is a citizen of Colombia and no other country based upon his uncontradicted oral testimony and the certified copy of the Colombian passport.6
CREDIBILITY
[21] The panel has considered the claimant's background as alleged, specifically that he is a 31-year-old man with a XXXX XXXX education and a background in XXXX in Colombia.
[22] The sworn testimony of a claimant is presumed to be truthful, unless there is valid reason to doubt its truthfulness.7
[23] The claimant was not a credible witness, in the panel's determination.
[24] On the basis of the cumulative credibility findings and negative inferences noted below, the panel determines that the claimant has failed to satisfy his burden of establishing a serious possibility he would be persecuted or he would be personally subjected to a risk to his life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a risk of torture by any authority or specific group in the Colombia.
[25] Credibility concerns include the following matters.
The Claimant's Attempt to pursue the Spousal Sponsorship after the End of the Marriage
[26] The Spousal Sponsorship documents include a letter from the Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada8 (IRCC) dated August 10, 2018 and addressed to the claimant advising that the processing of the application for permanent residence would be finalized at an interview on August 16, 2018 at the IRCC office in Etobicoke, requiring the personal attendance of the sponsoring spouse as well as the claimant.
[27] Next, a letter dated August 21, 20189 from IRCC advised the claimant that the Officer had determined that his Application for Permanent Residence under the Spouse or Common-Law Partner in Canada Class did not meet the requirements. It was specifically noted that, "We received correspondence from your sponsor requesting to withdraw her sponsorship application on 16 August 2018."
[28] Furthermore, the letter referred to an enclosed Voluntary Confirmation of Departure form which the claimant was asked to present to Immigration officials at his port of exit, and the claimant was informed that since he was "...currently in Canada without temporary resident status, you are required to leave Canada within thirty [30] days from the date of this letter. If you fail to confirm your departure from Canada, enforcement action to remove you from Canada will result."
[29] Another important document here is the Citizenship and Immigration Canada Official receipt10, dated August 20, 2018 at 00:42:58, indicating that the claimant used his credit card to pay the online Sponsorship fee of $490.
[30] The claimant testified at the hearing that his spouse broke up with him and left the marital home on XXXX XXXX, 2018. She told him she was never returning. She said "This is over. It is done"
[31] The panel asked why he had paid the online fee for the sponsorship on August 20 if the marriage had broken down. He replied that he did not know she had cancelled the sponsorship. He repeated, "She never told me that she had cancelled the sponsorship".
[32] The panel was puzzled by the claimant's comments. Did he not appreciate that attempting to obtain status in Canada through the spousal sponsorship, even after the marriage had broken down and the spouse had deserted him, may be construed as immigration fraud? The claimant was unrepentant, and maintained that he had been surprised by his spouse's letter to Canadian immigration officials on August 16, 2018 withdrawing her sponsorship application.
[33] Then he changed his answer to explain his attempt to complete the sponsorship application process, and claimed that he had hoped to reconcile with the spouse, and maybe in time to continue the marriage. The panel found his changing answers for this important question to be evasive.
[34] The panel finds and determines that the claimant's attempt to pursue and finalize the spousal sponsorship, even after his wife had left the marital home and ended the relationship, is clear evidence of a misrepresentation of a central element of his sponsorship. The claimant was effectively holding himself out to Canadian immigration officials as an applicant continuing in a genuine marriage to a Canadian permanent resident, when that was clearly not the case and he knew it was untrue. This undermines his overall credibility.The Claimant's Evidence that a Letter would allow him to escape further Harm in 2013
[35] The claimant testified that nobody else in the XXXX organization had any problems previously. Why did he think that he had such misfortune? He said because he considers himself a social activist. Were not the others also? He said that the volunteers were just volunteers, but the XXXX such as himself were the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. He noted XXXX has no internet website.
[36] The panel asked him whether there were any problems for anyone else in XXXX after he left Colombia. He testified that he did not know because he decided to separate himself from his problems. The panel asked him if he did not want to know more about the ongoing work of the organization. He said that he was the only person in this family who worked with the organization. He only told one person in the organization about his problems, XXXX XXXX XXXX.
[37] That person allegedly issued a letter of reference to him dated XXXX 201311. Why had he obtained it at that time? He said that he got it then as it was the only way for him to indicate the end of his campaign helping those communities. He pointed to the final paragraph of the letter which "certifies" that he was involved in "XXXX and voluntary field works" between 2011 and 2013, and "which were completed in XXXX 2013 due to direct death threats against [him]"
[38] The panel asked if he had planned to use this letter in 2013, and he replied that he obtained it in case he had any further problems from the Urabenos before he left Colombia. He added "If they were to attack me during the time it took me to leave the country, that's the reason I asked for the letter". He said that it was the only way he saw to save his life while he was leaving the country; he could show the letter to anyone from the Urabenos, and specifically the sentence where it stated that he had completed or ended his work with XXXX.
[39] The panel did not understand his explanation.
[40] What use would the letter be if they had attacked him again before he left Colombia? He replied, "If they were to attack me I could show them (the Urabenos) that I no longer work for them (XXXX), and that I was on my way out of the country".
[41] The panel asked the claimant if he thought that the Urabenos would take the time to read the letter if they were about to attack him.
[42] He replied that "Maybe it sounds stupid", but he thought it was all he could think of in his desperation.
[43] The panel also noted the pristine condition of the six-year-old letter. The claimant explained that he had carried it with him at all times in a briefcase while in Colombia.
[44] The panel finds that the claimant's explanation regarding the reason to obtain this letter strains credulity.
[45] He gave oral testimony otherwise at the hearing, that: (i) starting in XXXX 2012 he was threatened not to continue his volunteer activities or he would be killed; (ii) in XXXX 2012 six members of the Urabenos group threatened him that this was his "last chance"12 then damaged his vehicle with their AK-47 assault rifles; and (iii) in XXXX 2013 he was attacked from behind with no warning by a member of the group who slashed him with a knife leaving a 5 inch gash on his XXXX.
[46] The country documentation on point speaks of the Clan de Golfo (Gulf Clan) also known as Urabeños or Autodefensas Gaitanistas de Colombia, as a prominent narco-paramilitary structure. The organization's scope is extensive. According to the IRB's Response to Information Request,13
INDEPAZ reports that in 2016, activities carried out by narcoparamilitary groups included: trafficking of narcotics (including control of cultivation areas and strategic points like airports and seaports, drug trafficking routes; production); control of mining areas; human trafficking; money-laundering; smuggling; prostitution networks; extortion; contract killings; confrontations with public security forces and assassinations of police officers; actions against the civilian population, including threats against and murders of social leaders and human rights defenders, murders, child recruitment and displacement; and provision of employment and control of activities of civilians in some municipalities
[47] The panel does not find it credible that the claimant, given his alleged history of violent problems from this group prior to XXXX 2013, would then think that a letter carried in his briefcase would be of any value in warding off any future attack by the Urabenos. Did he expect them to give him forewarning of the next episode? Did he think that they would take the time to read his letter? Would one expect the Urabenos, given their history of extreme violence and crime in Colombia, to care about such a document?
[48] The panel did not understand why he would think that the paramilitary group would afford him the time to reach into his briefcase to produce the letter. The XXXX 2013 attack was allegedly done by surprise and even before that, in XXXX 2012, he had been told that was his "last chance". Counsel interjected during oral evidence and said that the claimant had said it may have been stupid.
[49] The panel is guided by the Federal Court of Appeal's decision in Shahamati,14 wherein Pratte, J.A., writing for the court, states, in part: "Contrary to what has sometimes been said, the Board is entitled, in assessing credibility, to rely on criterion such as rationality and common sense."
[50] In the panel's view, the claimant's incredible explanation about the reason he obtained this letter undermines his general credibility, and calls into question the provenance and genuineness of the document. The panel therefore finds that it can attach no weight to the letter. The panel is not convinced, on a balance of probabilities, that this document is genuine. Instead the panel finds that it has been procured solely to support a fraudulent refugee protection claim.
The Delay leaving Colombia in 2013
[51] The panel asked him why he had not left earlier? He said that as soon as they threatened him as a military target in XXXX 2013 he began to do things to leave. He said he did not have the money to buy the air ticket. He testified at the hearing that he sold his assets. Why was that not in the BOC Narrative? He said "Because it's personal". "I did not think it was necessary", he added.
[52] The panel asked for his comments given that question 2(f) of the BOC asks "Why did you leave at that time and not sooner, or at a later time?". He replied that he did not know the form that was in.
[53] While it is noted that the claimant's Canadian Temporary Resident visa was issued on XXXX XXXX, 201315, the claimant did not testify that the delay was due to any challenge or difficulty in obtaining that visitor's visa. The last incident with the alleged agents of persecution was in XXXX 2013, but the claimant did not leave Colombia until XXXX XXXX, 2013, - approximately four months later.
[54] The panel finds that the claimant has failed to adduce credible and trustworthy evidence to explain his delay leaving Colombia as he has omitted any attempt to address that point in his BOC despite specific instructions to do so, in the form.
[55] The Federal Court has observed that: "It is trite that one who fears for their life can reasonably be expected to leave their country of origin and claim status at the first opportunity, and the Court has been consistent in this regard".16 Mr. Justice Shore stated in Rahim17 that "[T]he time it takes an applicant to leave his or her country of origin can be taken into account in determining whether that person had a subjective fear of persecution." Delay in leaving the country if a claimant alleges he or she had reason to fear persecution there can call into question the credibility of the fear, and the panel determines it does so in the claimant's case. The panel draws an adverse inference accordingly.
The Delay claiming in Canada: 2013-2018
[56] The claimant arrived in Canada in XXXX XXXX, 2013, but did not advance his refugee protection claim for a full five years, - until September 17, 2018.
[57] In his BOC Narrative, he states that he had been invited to come to Canada many times by some of his friends, and decided to use the opportunity to come here "...For a while until some time passed"18 The panel asked the claimant if he was not afraid of being arrested after his visitor visa permission to stay in Canada expired and being deported? He replied that he was.
[58] The claimant alleges that a substantial part of the delay in claiming was due to his hope that he would be sponsored by his Canadian permanent resident spouse. But here it is noted that the marriage did not take place until XXXX XXXX, 201619 which is three years after the claimant's arrival in Canada. The panel also noted that the Sponsorship documents were not signed for filing until August 14, 2017.20
[59] When the panel asked the claimant to explain the extensive delay, the claimant first replied that he did not think it was necessary to claim while Colombia was going through a peace process. The panel queried that answer as the panel considered that any peace process was in reference to the rebel political group, FARC, not regarding the Gulf Cartel or Urabenos. Nevertheless, the claimant repeated his earlier answer. He said that when the peace process began it included all the armed groups in Colombia.
[60] However, in his oral submissions at the conclusion of the hearing, the claimant's counsel stated unequivocally that the Urabenos have never been in peace talks.
[61] The panel has carefully reviewed the country documentation and finds that there is no persuasive or credible evidence regarding Colombia to suggest that the Urabenos criminal narco-paramilitary group was involved in any peace process, or reduced their activities.
[62] In reality, the country condition documentation points to an opposite theory and conclusion from the claimant's: that the government's peace negotiations with FARC, and the concomitant reduction in FARC's activities led to regional power vacuums which were filled by groups such as the Urabenos whose influence increased as they exploited FARC's waning activity and that of other political groups.
[63] According to an IRB Response to Information Request21,
"...[W]hile the [Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC)] accord has
significantly reduced overall violence in the country, the demobilization of
these fighters has created vacuums throughout the country, which are in turn
being occupied by paramilitary successor organizations that are making
their presence known through selective killings and death threats. (WOLA
15 Feb. 2017)
According to a 2017 article by the Peace and Reconciliation Foundation (Fundación Paz
y Reconciliación) [2], illegal armed groups are arriving in FARC-vacated areas before the
Colombian Armed Forces (Fundación Paz y Reconciliación 13 Feb. 2017)"
[64] Another respected source, Colombia Reports22, states:
"Colombia has a number of powerful drug trafficking organizations, who have tried to take control of drug trafficking previously controlled by the country's largest guerrilla group in modern history, the FARC.
The Gaitanista Self-Defense Forces of Colombia(AGC) are by far the largest and most powerful of drug trafficking organizations in Colombia, controlling much of the most profitable link in the drug trafficking chain, export.
The paramilitary group is known as "Los Urabeños" by locals and called "Clan del Golfo" by authorities. Since its formation at the order of AUC founder Vicente Castaño in 2006, the group has violently taken control of both the Caribbean and Pacific coast lines of Colombia, usurping most criminal rackets left vacant by the AUC.
According to Police authorities, the group has grown from 250 to 3,000 members over the past decade. The AGC itself has claimed to have 8,000 members, "including informants" presumably in civil society, the military and politics.
The group is led by "Otoniel," a former Medellin cartel assassin and mid-level commander of the AUC. The group has repeatedly requested to be included in Colombia's ongoing peace process, but to no avail." [Emphasis added]
[65] The panel notes that last sentence confirms that the AGC, - also known as the Urabenos or Clan del Golfo, - was not involved in the peace process.
[66] The panel prefers the objective country documentation over the claimant's unfounded assertions to explain the reasons for his extensive delay making his refugee protection claim in Canada. Therefore, and in light of counsel's submissions which concur that the Urabenos were never involved in the peace process, the panel does not find the claimant's explanation credible, and draws an adverse inference.
[67] The panel finds that the claimant has failed to justify the lengthy delay in claiming refugee protection.
[68] Absent credible corroborative evidence to explain the delay in claiming refugee protection, it has been held reasonable for the RPD to conclude that this delay was incompatible with the alleged subjective fear23.
[69] The panel has considered delay in the assessment of the overall testimony. Delay is an important factor to be considered in this case. The claimant delayed for five years after he arrived in Canada before making his claim and then only claimed refugee status after he had been told to leave by IRCC. The jurisprudence on delay is clear.
[70] The claimant has failed to give a reasonable explanation in the panel's estimation for the delay. Delay can undermine both subjective fear and credibility if the claimant does not give a reasonable explanation for the delay in making a claim once he is in this country, and out of the country of persecution. The panel finds it has undermined both in this case.
[71] In the specific circumstances of this claim, the panel is mindful that while delays need not be determinative, they can fatally impugn a claimant's credibility such that the claim is rejected.24
[72] Although delay in filing an asylum application is not critical to the fate of all asylum applications, it may, in appropriate cases, in itself constitute a sufficient ground for rejection. This will usually be the case when the asylum seeker cannot provide a satisfactory explanation for his slowness to act.25
[73] The panel finds that this claim is appropriate for such a determination, in all the circumstances.
Major Omissions regarding the Description of the XXXX 2013 Incident
[74] The claimant testified that he had been declared a "Military Target" by the agents of persecution in XXXX 2013.
[75] When he was asked to describe that event in his oral testimony, the given account differed remarkably from that found in the BOC Narrative.
[76] The BOC Narrative states, "In XXXX 2013, when leaving the XXXX 'XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, after XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was attacked by a male in uniform who informed me that I had 6 months to leave the country, I would be declared 'Military Target' after this time".
[77] By comparison, in his oral testimony he said that while he was leaving the XXXX XXXX in Medellin, 300 metres ahead a man who was wearing the uniform of the Urabenos attacked him on his back, and told the claimant that: he had been warned twice; using an insult which the interpreter specified falls somewhere between "son of a bitch" and "mother fucker" as translated; he had six months to leave the country; and "We have declared you a Military Target". The man also told the claimant that he could not return to the country because "Being a Military Target for us is a law, and you will die if you return".
[78] The claimant testified that he identified the man's uniform as being from the group because it was "a normal military uniform, but on this arm (the claimant gestured to the upper left arm) they have a red flag". He described this as being about 5 inches, or 15 centimetres long.
[79] The claimant was asked to describe the attack. He said that the man attacked him on his XXXX with a knife. He said "He could have cut me on my XXXX. Then he said the attacker had cut him on his XXXX, with a small knife in an upward motion on his XXXX XXXX around the XXXX, leaving a cut which was about 5 inches long through the claimant's XXXX.
[80] Why was there no mention of the knife assault in the BOC Narrative? The claimant replied that he stated there that the man "attacked" him.
[81] The panel asked why the details were not given, as the BOC instructions indicate26. He replied, "I didn't detail it because the word 'attack' in Spanish, it could be that."
[82] The panel finds that the claimant's response is evasive, unsatisfactory, and unreasonable. The written narrative is vague with respect to details regarding the attack. If the claimant had been stabbed or slashed with a knife that would be an important aspect of the assault and a specific example of potentially life-threatening persecution by the Urabenos.
[83] The Federal Court has repeatedly confirmed that the accumulation of contradictions between a claimant's testimony, Port of Entry [POE] statements and Personal Information Form [PIF] may legitimately serve as a basis for a negative credibility finding.27 In Fang, the Federal court noted
Although the applicant is correct that this Court has held that lack of details in a PIF and port of entry notes do not automatically lead to an adverse credibility finding, the Board is entitled to draw a negative inference from an applicant's failure to mention significant facts in his or her PIF and IMM 5611 form (Akhigbe v Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration), 2002 FCT 249, [2002] FCJ 332 at para 15; Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration) v Richards, 2004 FC 1218 at para 19). In Kin v Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration), 2005 FC 282 at para 23, Justice Anne Mactavish stated that "[t]he nature of the omission, and the context in which the new information is brought forward, have to be examined in order to determine the materiality of the omission." 28
[84] The claimant did not provide any medical document about the knife wound; he said the cut was not very deep so he did not seek treatment.
[85] The claimant provided a letter of corroboration allegedly from a security guard at the XXXX. The guard asserts that from the door of the XXXX he was able to observe "... About 300 m ahead, a man in a military uniform and with Urabenos badges attacked [the claimant] ..."29
[86] The panel does not believe that anyone could make out the detail of such a badge, as described above by the claimant, at a distance of 300 meters (1,000 feet).
[87] The panel draws a further negative credibility inference.
[88] Given these credibility concerns the panel is not convinced, on a balance of probabilities, that this incident occurred.
The BOC lacks Details regarding the alleged XXXX 2012 Incident
[89] In his BOC Narrative, the claimant stated30:
"Around XXXX 2012, I was stopped while driving, by individuals in uniforms who told me that they were the Urabenos; they stole our belongings, money and the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. They damaged our vehicle and one of them told me that I had been warned a few months earlier, that I should listen to this last chance".
[90] By comparison, in his oral testimony the claimant alleged that there were six combatants from the Urabenos who surrounded the XXXX XXXX, swore at him calling him a "puta" (whore), and bashed in the body work on the driver's side of the car with the butt of their AK-47s.
[91] The panel asked him why his BOC narrative did not give these details, such as the number or that they were heavily armed. He said that "You're asking me for details and that would make the narrative very long." He added, "In the narrative it says they attacked me".
[92] The panel disagrees, and finds that the BOC Narrative lacks the pertinent details which would otherwise illustrate the degree of risk to the claimant, including the number of gang members and the fact that they were armed with assault rifles. The panel draws a further adverse credibility inference as a consequence.
[93] With respect to the content and level of detail of PIF (now "BOC") narratives, the Federal Court stated in Basseghi:
It is not incorrect to say that answers given in a PIF should be brief but it is incorrect to say that the answers should not be complete with all of the relevant details. It is not enough (for a claimant) to say that what he said in oral testimony was an elaboration. All relevant and important facts should be included in one's PIF. The oral evidence should go on to explain the information contained in the PIF [emphasis in original].31
[94] The panel asked the claimant whether he had any report or insurance claim regarding the vehicle damage, but he replied that he did not report the matter to anyone else, even at the XXXX organization. He said that he did not have to explain the vehicle damage to anyone, and had the body work repaired secretly.
[95] The claimant did not provide any body shop receipt to corroborate the vehicle damage, or any ownership papers. He did provide three pictures32 showing the side of a damaged motor vehicle, but not showing the make, model, or a license plate. In the panel's view, the photographs have no inherent probative value. There is nothing except the claimant's oral testimony to connect these pictures to his allegations; they could have been taken at any time, in any country, with any person's motor vehicle.
[96] Given the credibility concerns already outlined, the panel gives these photographs little evidentiary weight.
[97] The panel asked the claimant why would he keep the Urabenos attack upon the vehicle secret from people in XXXX? He replied enigmatically, "Why do people need to know what happens to me if some of the people who know are not interested".
[98] The panel asked him why he thought that people would be disinterested in the attack upon him by the Urabenos? The claimant replied, "If I'm the XXXX from XXXX Colombia I have no reason to tell anyone else what was happening to me if I feel that the threats are personal."
[99] The claimant expressed the same thoughts when he explained why he allegedly kept the initial threatening phone call from the Urabenos in XXXX 2012 secret from others in the XXXX organization.
[100] In the panel's view, the claimant was not credible regarding the reasons for the alleged secrecy. The first threat received, according to the claimant, was that he was warned not to return to the Commune where he, in his capacity as an XXXX and volunteer for XXXX, was allegedly engaged in a XXXX XXXX in a marginalized zone. Furthermore, he alleges that he was one of two or three XXXX, but there were many other volunteers. In the panel's view, the claimant was not persuasive nor credible in this aspect of testimony.
[101] The panel finds that the claimant's credibility is further impugned by his incomprehensible rationalization of the secrecy regarding alleged threats from the Urabenos.
The Timing of the Refugee Protection Claim
[102] As noted above, the Spousal Sponsorship documents include a letter dated August 21, 201833 from Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada [IRCC] advising the claimant that the Officer had determined that his Application for Permanent Residence under the Spouse or Common-Law Partner in Canada Class did not meet the requirements. Furthermore, the letter enclosed a Voluntary Confirmation of Departure form which the claimant was asked to present to Immigration officials at his port of exit, and the claimant was informed that since he was "...currently in Canada without temporary resident status, you are required to leave Canada within thirty [30] days from the date of this letter. If you fail to confirm your departure from Canada, enforcement action to remove you from Canada will result."
[103] Thus, it is clear that the claimant knew that he would be unable to prolong his stay in Canada.
[104] He alleged in his oral testimony that in XXXX, when he telephoned his family in Colombia to tell them that he wanted to leave Canada, he was advised by them that he should "... Stay away from Colombia as the Urabenos had resurfaced this year and continued their killings, harassments and threats, and that I was being sought by them, as I had been deemed a Military Target and 'punishment' should be enforced".
[105] He said that his brother had received a phone call some time before XXXX. The panel asked him for a date. The claimant replied that his brother told him it was some months before but did not tell him when. The panel asked why he did not ask his brother for the precise date. The claimant replied that the date is not important, the issue is that it happened.
[106] The panel asserted that given the instructions in the BOC requesting details throughout the questions, the date is important, and asked the claimant why he had not obtained this information from his brother. He repeated his earlier response that he did not think it important.
[107] The claimant testified at the oral hearing that the Urabenos telephoned his brother, identified themselves, told the brother that they knew who he was, and he was the brother of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX (the claimant), whom they had identified as a Military Target, and if he returned to Colombia "we would annihilate him".
[108] The panel notes that the BOC Narrative does not mention the alleged specific and direct telephone contact to his brother. The BOC is vague in this important area also as it only states that "...The Urabenos had resurfaced this year and... That I was being sought by them...".
[109] The claimant's explanation was that he "honestly" did not see it as necessary to mention that his brother had received a telephone call or the details.
[110] In the panel's view, this is a further important omission because it would indicate the ability of the agents of persecution to trace and find the claimant's closest family members in Colombia in their search for him, and thus both the resources of the Urabenos and the extent to which they would pursue him if he were to return. Moreover, it would also illustrate a latent risk for the claimant's family members.
[111] The panel draws a further negative credibility inference from the lack of details in the BOC Narrative on this important point.
[112] When asked why his family members had not warned him before XXXX 2018, he replied that they had only warned him after he telephoned to Colombia to say he might return, even though he testified that he spoke to them twice every week by telephone.
[113] The claimant also tendered in evidence a copy of a flyer or pamphlet34 which he said the Urabenos had scattered around the city on the ground. He said that his brother never told him the date this had been found either, but he had learned of it after the BOC Narrative was drafted.
[114] Why would the Urabenos start looking for him again in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 2018, when there is no evidence of any interest in the claimant between XXXX 2013 and XXXX 2018? The claimant said that there had been a peace process during that time. The panel asked if he knew of any explanation for this sudden resurgence of interest in him?
[115] The claimant said that they had told him to leave the country. And this was the law for as long as a terrorist group was alive, and he was. He said that during that five-year period he did not return to Colombia for fear of his life. He did not attempt to address the panel's concern directly.
[116] The nub of the claimant's present fear of return to Colombia is that the Urabenos, suddenly and for no apparent reason after a five-year hiatus while the claimant was in Canada, came looking for him, and this only came to his attention in the weeks immediately following the issuance of a letter by Canadian immigration officials telling him to leave.
[117] The panel asked the claimant if he had any further explanation, given the remarkable coincidence of timing, that the threat from the Urabenos was apparently dormant for five years then he learned it had returned within thirty days after he was told to leave the country by Canadian immigration officials following the aborted spousal sponsorship.
[118] He replied that they had pronounced him to be a Military Target, and then during the time in Canada and the sponsorship by his wife that threat was still continuing and in force.
[119] So, the panel asked, why had he not made his refugee claim if he thought the threat was still there? He replied that he was waiting for peace in Colombia. The panel is of the view that the claimant's answer that "the threat was still there" in Colombia throughout his time in Canada, was inconsistent with his earlier answers to justify the delay in claiming.
[120] The panel finds that the claimant's above explanations were inconsistent, vague, lacking in detail and not forthcoming. The panel finds that the claimant did not reasonably explain why the Urabenos had a sudden renewed interest in him in 2018. Therefore, the panel finds that the flyer or pamphlet was not circulated by the Urabenos in 2018 as alleged.The applicable credibility principle is well elucidated by the British Columbia Court of Appeal in Faryna v. Chorny, wherein O'Halloran, J.A., stated, in part, as follows: "In short, the real test of the truth of the story of a witness in such a case must be its harmony with the preponderance of the probabilities which a practical and informed person would readily recognize as reasonable in that place, and in those conditions."35
[121] The panel finds that the claimant's assertions in this area of testimony beg belief.
The Claimant's Inconsistent Evidence regarding his Involvement in the XXXX Organization, XXXX
[122] The claimant alleged that there were three organizers for events conducted by XXXX, and thousands of volunteers over the lifespan of the organization. He testified that he began in XXXX 2011 as an XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. He said that the organization chose the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. He alleged that his organization XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. He was on the formal staff, but was unpaid even though he worked around 24 hours per week on average.
[123] In the Schedule A Background/Declaration, which the claimant filed as part of his refugee protection claim on September 13, 2018,36 it indicates that he was a XXXX XXXX XXXX (he said that was the same as an XXXX) at XXXX during dates starting in XXXX 2013 and ending in XXXX 2012 (sic) as well as a volunteer between XXXX 2011 and XXXX 2013. By comparison, in the Spousal Sponsorship documents there is a second, earlier, Schedule A Background/Declaration37 filed before the refugee protection claim, and dated January 16, 2018, where there is no mention whatsoever of XXXX, either under the heading of Personal History or in question 7 regarding Membership or Association with organizations.
[124] The claimant was asked to explain. He said that he had not filled out the sponsorship documents because he did not know enough English, he had just signed it. He blamed his former counsel and his former wife. He agreed that another accredited immigration consultant, XXXX XXXX, who is named in the spousal sponsorship documents, had assisted in the completion of these forms. The panel asked him if he had any further explanation given that he had signed a Declaration for the form attesting that the information given therein was "truthful, complete and correct". He said that his ex-wife and XXXX had never asked him if he was a volunteer. He added that he didn't know what the forms were asking for, and they did not ask him.
[125] The panel member determines that the claimant's explanation is not credible. The claimant blamed the other consultant, but did not give that individual a chance to address the concerns raised or provide any letter of corroboration from him to confirm the claimant's oral testimony about the omission. The claimant specifically mentioned XXXX in the RPD claim Schedule A twice, regarding both Personal History and Membership or Association with organizations. Even a cursory review by a non-English speaker of the Spousal Sponsorship Schedule A, would have revealed that XXXX is not mentioned.38
[126] In light of the lack of evidence corroborating the claimant's explanation that the omission in the Spousal Sponsorship Schedule A was the fault of his consultant and/or of his ex-wife, and given the numerous other credibility concerns with the claimant's testimony, the panel finds that it is more likely than not that XXXX is not mentioned in the form because the claimant did not volunteer or work there.
The Photographs of the Claimant's Father
[127] The disclosure from the claimant includes pictures of him with his father, and allegedly with volunteers from XXXX39. However, he indicates in both the Schedule A, Background/Declaration 40 and in his BOC41 that his father died in XXXX 2008. And to repeat, in his BOC Narrative he states that he only became a volunteer for XXXX starting in XXXX 2011,42 and the refugee claim Schedule gives the same date - well after his father's death. The panel finds that these photographs are of no obvious relevance to the claim, and there is nothing in the photographs, apparently taken inside a building showing the claimant and his father with two women, which appears to have anything to do with the claimant's alleged problems. The panel finds the photographs have no probative value with respect to the claimant's alleged risk, and thus gives them no weight.
The Claimant's Other Supporting Documentation
[128] The timing of the refugee claim, combined with the numerous other credibility concerns outlined above, lead the panel to find that the Urabenos do not have, and have never had, any interest in the claimant.
[129] In light of the numerous and significant credibility concerns outlined above, the panel attaches little or no weight to the other supporting documentation provided by the claimant,including the alleged threatening note from the agents of persecution43 letters from his mother and brother44, the letter from the alleged security guard, and the two general letters of recommendation45 The panel finds that they are not capable of outweighing the important and numerous negative credibility inferences noted above.
[130] While the two general letters of recommendation assert that the claimant was involved in the XXXX organization46, neither letter writer was proffered as a witness at the hearing, despite their having listed local Toronto area codes.Furthermore, the content of the two letters was brief and the format was almost identical as each contained three paragraphs in which the first introduced the claimant by name, asserting that he had been known since he was a child, and the second referred to the claimant's father by name and as the "founder of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX"47, then to the claimant's link to XXXX as "a volunteer XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX48" or someone who "began to develop a love for helping others." 49
[131] The panel is therefore not convinced that these letters were written independently, or without specific direction by the claimant, and the panel gives them little weight.
SUMMARY
[132] As noted above, numerous, important credibility concerns arose from the claimant's evidence.
[133] The panel did not find the claimant to be a credible witness, and simply does not believe his allegations about problems with the Urabenos in Colombia, or that he was actively involved in XXXX as alleged. The panel further finds that the claimant has failed to adduce sufficient credible and trustworthy evidence regarding the claim to convince the panel, on a balance of probabilities, that any of these events happened as alleged.
[134] The panel further finds on a balance of probabilities, given the numerous important negative credibility findings and inferences, that all supporting documentation provided by the claimant about his alleged problems in Colombia, including the alleged threatening note from the agents of persecution50, letters from his mother and brother51, and the letter from the alleged security guard.,52 are fraudulent documents procured to support the fraudulent refugee protection claim.
[135] The Federal Court has often found that a general lack of credibility can extend to supporting evidence, trickling down to other elements of the claim, and can be generalized to all of the documentary evidence presented to corroborate a version of the facts It is open to the RPD not to give evidentiary weight to supporting letters if underlying elements are found not credible.53
[136] In Gebetas54 Mr. Justice Shore noted,
[29] As stated by this Court numerous times, general findings of lack of credibility can affect all relevant evidence submitted by an applicant, including documentary evidence, and ultimately cause the rejection of a claim (Ayub v Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration), 2004 FC 1411 at para 8-9; Nijjer v Canada (Ministry of Citizenship and Immigration), 2009 FC 1259; Alonso v Canada (Minister Citizenship and Immigration), 2008 FC 683).
[30] The Court also finds that the RPD did not err in attributing significant weight to the omissions in the Applicant's POE document. This Court has repeatedly confirmed that the accumulation of contradictions between a claimant's testimony, POE statements and PIF may legitimately serve as a basis for a negative credibility finding (Trochez, above; Cienfuegos, above).
CONCLUSION
[137] Given the credibility concerns as noted, the Panel makes a general finding of a lack of credibility regarding the claimant.
[138] The Panel concludes that the claimant, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection, and therefore rejects his claim.
[139] Furthermore, the panel determines that there was no credible or trustworthy evidence on which a favourable decision could have been made, and finds that there is no credible basis for the claim pursuant to subsection 107(2) of the IRPA.
[140] The panel is mindful of the decision of Mr. Justice Hugessen of the Federal Court of Appeal in Urbanek,55 where he states:
The appellant's position is based on a fundamental misconception of Canada's refugee system; the purpose of the system is to provide safe haven to those who genuinely need it and not to give a quick and convenient route to landed status for immigrants who cannot or will not obtain it in the usual way.
[141] The panel is of the view that the claimant is in a similar situation as the appellant in Urbanek.

REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] This is the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) in the claim of XXXX XXXX XXXX who is a citizen of Angola and is claiming refugee protection pursuant to Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the "Act").1
[2] I have reviewed and applied the Chairperson's Guideline on Women Refugee Claimants Fearing Gender-Related Persecution in this decision.2
ALLEGATIONS
[3] The principal claimant has outlined her reasons for seeking Canada's protection in her Basis of Claim (BOC) form3, her updated narrative4, as well as through her testimony. The principal claimant fears returning to Angola because she fears XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, a former XXXX XXXX.
[4] The claimant was born and grew up in Cabinda, the capital city of the Angolan province with the same name. The province of Cabinda, which is bordered on the west by the Atlantic Ocean, is separated from the rest of Angola by a narrow strip of territory belonging to the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
[5] The claimant moved to Luanda, the capital city of Angola, in 2008. The claimant alleges that a car rear ended her in Luanda in XXXX 2017. The car that hit her belonged to the XXXX XXXX XXXX, a company owned by Mr. XXXX. The police were present at the scene and according to the claimant the company signed a police report declaring they would repair the claimant's car.
[6] In XXXX 2017, the claimant met with Mr. XXXX regarding her vehicle and he reiterated that the XXXX XXXX XXXX would fix her car.
[7] In XXXX 2017, the claimant wrote a letter to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence asking the Secretary of Judicial and Legal Affairs of the Presidency of the Republic to resolve the issue regarding her car with the XXXX XXXX XXXX. On XXXX XXXX, 2017, the claimant received a response5 stating that the matter should be resolved with the XXXX XXXX XXXX.
[8] Following this the claimant alleges that Mr. XXXX phoned her and threatened her for sending the letter to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence.
[9] The claimant stated that she received four other calls from a private number and that the individual on the phone told her that she was an enemy of the country and that at any moment she could disappear. After this she no longer answered calls from private numbers, changed her phone number and no longer received any calls threatening her.
[10] The claimant alleges two kidnapping attempts, one on XXXX XXXX, 2017, where the police intervened as they were near by, and one on XXXX XXXX, 2017, where her co-workers intervened.
[11] The claimant testified that she went to the National Department of Criminal Investigation in XXXX 2017 to open an investigation and was asked for her political membership card for the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MLAP), the ruling party in Angola. The claimant was told that if she did not have her membership card, the police would not help her open a complaint.
[12] The claimant stated that she has a membership card with The Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda (FLEC), but that she did not inform the police of this information.
[13] The claimant alleged that she was kidnapped in XXXX 2017. She stated that she was threatened for her political affiliations with FLEC and heard the kidnappers refer to her reaching out to the Presidency. She testified that she was released on the side of the road two days later with a warning from her kidnappers that they could come back for her.
[14] The claimant went to stay in Caxito, the capital city of the Angolan province of Bengo, for a month and a half. In XXXX 2017, the claimant moved back to Luanda where she lived with various friends. The claimant travelled to the United States in XXXX 2018 and reached Canada on XXXX XXXX, 2018, where she sought refugee protection.
DETERMINATION
[15] I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.
[16] The determinative issue in this case is the availability of an Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) for the claimant in the city of Cabinda.
ANALYSIS
Identity
[17] The claimant's identity as a national of Angola is established by her testimony and the certified copy of her Angolan passport in evidence.6
Credibility
[18] Unless specifically noted in the analysis below, I accept the claimant's evidence about the events she encountered in Angola as being generally credible. However, this presumption does not apply to inferences (conclusions drawn from facts) or speculation (for which there is no evidentiary basis).
[19] I am accepting that the following occurred:
* Mr. XXXX is a former XXXX XXXX in Angola;
* A car owned by the XXXX XXXX XXXX rear-ended the claimant's car in 2017;
* The claimant wrote and received a response from the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence;
* Mr. XXXX threatened the claimant following her letter to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence;
* The claimant had her purse taken in XXXX XXXX, 2017; and,
* The claimant was kidnapped in XXXX 2017 for two days and released.
Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
[20] The determinative issue is IFA. This issue was raised with the principal claimant during the hearing. I find that the claimant has a viable IFA in the city of Cabinda. To find a viable IFA, I am guided by the decision of the Federal Court of Appeal in Rasaratnam,7 which defined the following two-pronged test for an IFA:
"...the Board must be satisfied on a balance of probabilities that there is no serious possibility of the claimant being persecuted or, on a balance of probabilities, being subjected personally to a danger of torture, a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in the part of the country to which it finds an IFA exists"
Moreover, conditions in the part of the country considered to be an IFA must be such that it would not be unreasonable, in all the circumstances, including those particular to the claimant, for him to seek refuge there.8
First Prong: Risk in the IFA
Agent of harm - Mr. XXXX
[21] I find that the claimant has not adduced sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the agent of harm, Mr. XXXX, has the means or the motivation to locate her and harm her in Cabinda.
Does Mr. XXXX have the means to locate the claimant in the IFA?
[22] I have considered whether Mr. XXXX has the means to locate the claimant in the IFA and I have found that he does not have the means.
[23] The claimant testified that Mr. XXXX would be able to locate her in Cabinda. When asked how, she stated that he would be locate her because of his work as the XXXX XXXX in Angola.
[24] I have accepted that Mr. XXXX was a XXXX XXXX. However, I find that the claimant has not established that he still has control over the police force. When asked if she knew if Mr. XXXX was a XXXX XXXX at the time of the car accident and if he was still a XXXX XXXX today, the claimant testified that she did not know. A news article in Exhibit 9 dated XXXX 2016 references Mr. XXXX as a former XXXX XXXX. The claimant testified that given Mr. XXXX's position he will have his power until his death and will have power over the police force in the whole country. Counsel referenced an article dated XXXX XXXX, 20189 that mentions Mr. XXXX's name to illustrate his reach. This article XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. This article provides limited context in terms of the scope of Mr. XXXX's involvement and also indicates that the matter is being addressed in the courts. As such, I give limited weight to the article.
[25] I also find that the claimant has not established that the police force has been biased in favour of Mr. XXXX. According to the objective evidence,
The national police, controlled by the Ministry of Interior, are responsible for internal security and law enforcement. The Criminal Investigation Services (SIC), also under the Ministry of Interior, are responsible for preventing and investigating domestic crimes (...) Civilian authorities maintained effective control over the (...) national police, and the government has mechanisms to investigate and punish abuse and corruption. The security forces generally were effective, although sometimes brutal, at maintaining stability.10
[26] The claimant testified that she sought the police's help on multiple occasions in Angola and that she had never had any problems with the police, though she stated that she does not think that they will do anything. I asked the claimant about the following documents from the police that she provided, which appeared to indicate that they were following up on her concerns:
* Notification of the loss of documents XXXX XXXX, 2017 from the Police Commando of the Municipality of XXXX,11
* Summons to give evidence dated XXXX XXXX, 2017 from the National Department of Criminal Investigation,12 and,
* Second notification to appear dated XXXX XXXX, 2018 from the National Department of Criminal Investigation.13
[27] The claimant stated that she did not trust the summons from the National Department of Criminal Investigation and that this was a ploy for the police to find her as it was sent after her alleged kidnapping when she was in hiding. Although I sympathize with the claimant's distress, I note that it is the claimant that approached the National Department of Criminal Investigation. I find that the claimant is speculating regarding the two summons received, and that there is insufficient evidence before me that would indicate, on the balance of probabilities, that the summons are a means for Mr. XXXX to locate the claimant.
[28] Based on the above, I find that Mr. XXXX did hold the position of XXXX XXXX at some time in Angola. I also find that the claimant repeatedly approached the police and that her testimony and documents provided showing the various interactions between herself and the police in Exhibits 7 and 9 does not support the claimant's allegation that the police is being biased towards the agent of harm. The actions taken by the police support, on a balance of probabilities, that they were taking the appropriate steps that could be expected in their position.
[29] I have insufficient evidence before me to establish, on a balance of probabilities, that Mr. XXXX has maintained control over the police force throughout Angola. As such, I find, on the balance of probabilities, that Mr. XXXX could not utilize the police force to locate the claimant.
Is Mr. XXXX motivated to locate the claimant in the IFA?
[30] I have also considered whether Mr. XXXX is sufficiently motivated to locate and harm the claimant in the IFA and I have found that he is not sufficiently motivated.
[31] Even accepting that Mr. XXXX threatened the claimant after she sent a letter to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence, and arranged for her to be kidnapped and released in XXXX 2017, there is no evidence before me that he has threatened the claimant since XXXX 2017. The claimant testified she lived with various friends in Luanda from XXXX 2017 to XXXX 2018 during which time she received no threats from Mr. XXXX. I find, on a balance of probabilities, that Mr. XXXX is not motivated to pursue the claimant in the IFA when he did not pursue her in Luanda from XXXX 2017 until her departure in XXXX 2018.
Alleged kidnappings
[32] The claimant testified that after she wrote a letter to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence asking the Secretary of Judicial and Legal Affairs of the Presidency of the Republic to resolve the agreement with the XXXX XXXX XXXX, Mr. XXXX, called her and threatened her.
[33] With regards to the alleged kidnapping attempts on XXXX XXXX, 2017, and XXXX XXXX, 2017, the claimant testified that she thinks that these are linked to Mr. XXXX because of the threats he had uttered to her on the phone. The claimant stated that she did not know the people involved in these incidents.
[34] Regarding the first alleged attempt, the claimant testified that a car approached her as she was leaving a bank. The claimant testified that a police car showed up and the car left the scene. I find that the claimant is speculating as to the motives of the individuals in the car, and that given her location at a bank, that the interest of the individuals in the car could have been financially motivated.
[35] With regards to the second alleged attempt, the claimant did provide testimonies14 from her colleagues corroborating that individuals tried to push the claimant into a car and that the individual in the car took her bag when her colleagues started running towards the claimant and the car. I note that the police did issue a police report regarding the reporting of loss documents with regards to this event.15 There is no mention of an attempted kidnapping in the police report. I give weight to the police report and as such, I find, on the balance of probabilities, that this incident was a robbery.
[36] I also accept, on the balance of probabilities, that the claimant was kidnapped for two days in XXXX 2017 and subsequently released. That during this time she heard the kidnappers say that she was an enemy of the MPLA given her FLEC membership and reference the letter she had sent to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence. As such, I find, on a balance of probabilities, that this incident is connected to Mr. XXXX. I recognize that this is a traumatizing experience. Following the incident, the claimant contacted her family and relocated to Bengo Caxito, which is 60 kilometers from Luanda for a month and a half and then returned to Luanda until her departure in XXXX 2018.
[37] I note an email dated XXXX XXXX, 201916 that indicates that four young men were looking for the claimant in 2018 and that a young man had showed up to her former place of employment in 2019 saying he had a delivery for her. The claimant believes that these individuals are working for Mr. XXXX. It is unclear why these individuals were looking for the claimant. As such, I find that the claimant is speculating regarding the motivation of these individuals. I find that there is insufficient evidence, on a balance of probabilities, to establish that these incidents, even if they did occur, were motivated by Mr. XXXX to find and harm the claimant.
[38] The claimant testified that since XXXX 2017 she has not received any threats. When asked if the claimant had any issues after leaving Angola in XXXX 2018, she testified that she did not.
[39] I find that the situation with the claimant and Mr. XXXX escalated following her letter to the Cabinet Juridique de la Présidence. I also find that it would be reasonable for the claimant to no longer pursue damages for her car in the proposed IFA.
[40] Angola is a large country of over 1 million square kilometres and over 35 million people. In the present case, there is insufficient evidence that Mr. XXXX would be motivated to pursue the claimant to Cabinda which is over 800 kilometers from Luanda and is separated from the rest of Angola by the Democratic Republic of the Congo when he did not locate her in Luanda from XXXX 2017 until her departure in XXXX 2018.
[41] Based on all of the evidence before me, where Mr. XXXX has not had direct or indirect contact with the claimant since the end of XXXX 2017, I find the claimant has not adduced sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the agent of harm has the motivation to locate and harm her in Cabinda. Accordingly, I find the claimant does not face a serious possibility of persecution or, on a balance of probabilities, a risk of subsection 97(1) harm or a danger of torture in Cabinda.
[42] I have also considered whether the claimant might face other Sections 96 or 97 risks in Cabinda based on her gender or membership in the FLEC.
[43] On the evidence before me, I find that the claimant does not face a serious possibility of persecution based on her gender as a women or on her imputed political opinion as a member of FLEC or, on a balance of probabilities, a danger of torture, a risk to life or a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment in Cabinda.
Gender
[44] The claimant's counsel has submitted that things are not easy for women in Angola and that the claimant faces a risk of sexual violence which renders not only the IFA location but a return to Angola unreasonable. The claimant's counsel submits that the claimant suffered from physical violence when she was kidnapped, that she was hit in the stomach by the assailants. She noted the documents in Exhibit 9 which speak to the difficulty's women face in Angola.
[45] I acknowledge that the claimant's fear as a woman needs to be considered when determining if she faces a serious possibility of being persecuted based on her gender under the first prong of the IFA.
[46] The objective evidence indicates that rape, including marital rape, is illegal in Angola where offenders can serve prisons sentences of up to ten years, depending on the severity of the crime (Penal Code, Art. 169-172, 2006).17 That although there are limited investigative resources, poor forensic capabilities, and an ineffective judicial system, that the Ministry of Justice and Human Rights worked with the Ministry of Interior to increase the number of female police officers and to improve police response to rape allegations.18
[47] I acknowledge that there is gender-based violence in Angola. I have considered the claimant's overall profile, as a female who has a XXXX XXXX XXXX education, has been employed in Angola and has the support of her extended family. I accept that the claimant was hit by the assailants when she was kidnapped and that this traumatized her. However, I find that this was an isolated incident and that the agent of harm in this instance, as outlined below, is no longer motivated and does not have the means to locate the claimant in the IFA. I also note that counsel's submission that the claimant may have been at risk of sexual assault during the kidnapping, but that it was averted, and that next time she may not be as lucky is speculative. I have considered the lack of any specific evidence pointing to individualized factors that may aggravate the claimants' risks of general crime and gender-based violence in the IFA. Weighing all the evidence before me, I do not find that the claimant faces a serious possibility of persecution based on her gender in Angola and more specifically in the IFA.
Political Profile of the Claimant
[48] I find that the claimant does have a membership to the FLEC.19 The claimant testified that her uncle had encouraged her to acquire it in 2012 because it would help facilitate her travel between Pointe-Noir and Luanda where she travelled to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. The claimant testified that she grew up in Cabinda and that everyone there is a member of FLEC, that it's not really a choice. When asked if she ever participated in any FLEC activities, she stated that she had not.
[49] According to the objective evidence, the conflict in Cabinda between the Angolan government and FLEC began in 1975. A peace agreement was signed in 2006. Since the peace agreement, some Cabindans have become members of the Angolan Government.
[50] Generally, there are no reports of ill treatment of Cabindans solely by virtue of being from Cabinda. Counsel submitted many reports in Exhibit 9 with regards to how members of FLEC have been treated by the government in Angola. I note that documents 2, 4, 5 and 7 are dated and reference events that date back between 2000-2007. The current objective evidence states that FLEC's composition and numbers are unknown and that in recent years, FLEC's ability has diminished to that of a propaganda war.20
[51] According to the objective evidence, the political landscape has evolved in Cabinda. While I acknowledge that there are reports that the government continues to arrest pro-independence Cabinda activists at rallies,21 there is no evidence before me that indicates that the human rights abuse against Cabinda activists is so widespread or systematic that the claimant would have problems.
[52] I find that the claimant, though she has a membership card to the FLEC, has had no involvement with the party. I have considered the lack of any specific evidence pointing to individualized factors that may aggravate the claimant's risks in the IFA based on her FLEC membership. Weighing all the evidence before me, I do not find that the claimant faces a serious possibility of persecution based on her imputed political opinion because of her FLEC memberships in Angola and more specifically in the IFA.
Two: Is it Reasonable for the Claimants to Relocate to Cabinda
[53] With respect to the second prong of the IFA test, , in Rasaratnam, the Court of Appeal held that once an IFA is raised as an issue, the onus is on the claimant to show that he or she does not have an IFA. The burden placed on the claimant is fairly high in order to show that the IFA is unreasonable. The test to show that the IFA is unreasonable, requires nothing less than the existence of conditions that would jeopardize the life and safety of the claimant in relocating to a safe place. Actual and concrete evidence of adverse conditions is required.
[54] The claimant stated that she would be unable to find employment in Cabinda and that her mother and extended family rely on her to provide them financial support. The claimant has a XXXX XXXX education, she previously worked for XXXX22 in Luanda and according to her testimony would travel to Pointe-Noir and back to Luanda to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. The claimant speaks Portuguese, Lingala, French and Kikingo. Based on her XXXX XXXX XXXX level of education, previous work experience and language proficiency, I find that she is well placed to find employment in Cabinda.
[55] The claimant and counsel submitted that the living conditions would not be conducive for her in Cabinda, though no concrete reasons of what would not be conducive were put forward. The claimant testified that her mother and brothers currently live in Cabinda and that she could live with her mother. As such, I find that the claimant would have the support of extended family if she were to relocate to Cabinda.
[56] Finally, I have also considered whether generalized crime or violence might make the proposed IFA unreasonable. According to the Angola 2019 Crime and Safety Report23 Angola is assessed at an overall level of 1, which is the lowest level of rating, indicating to individuals to exercise normal precautions in Angola. I have considered the claimant's overall profile, as a female who has a XXXX XXXX XXXX education and extended family in the IFA. I have considered the lack of any specific evidence pointing to individualized factors that may aggravate the claimants' risks of general crime and gender-based violence in the IFA. Weighing all the evidence before me I am not satisfied that the crime in the proposed IFA rises to the high level contemplated at the second prong of the IFA test.
[57] Considering all of the evidence before me, I find that it is objectively reasonable in all the circumstances, including the claimant's particular circumstances, for her to relocate to Cabinda and therefore I find that she has a viable IFA in Cabinda. Since having a viable IFA is fatal to claims made under both Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Act, the claim fails under both grounds.
CONCLUSION
[58] I find that the claimant is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. The claim for protection is dismissed.
