REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] This is the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) in the claims of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ("the principal claimant"), XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ("the associate claimant"), and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ("the minor claimant") as citizens of Colombia who are claiming refugee protection pursuant to section 96 and subsection 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the "Act").1
[2] I heard these claims jointly pursuant to Rule 55 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules. At the hearing the principal claimant, who is the mother of the minor claimant, acted as the designated representative for her, pursuant to subsection 167(2) of the "Act" and Rule 20 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules. She was provided with an opportunity to testify about any risk that the minor claimant faces. Both the principal and the associate claimants were provided with the opportunity to testify about the events in question.
ALLEGATIONS
[3] The claimants, who are from XXXX, allege a fear of an armed group which they say is composed of former members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and has ties to the National Liberation Army (ELN). The claimants allege that this armed group tried to extort them because the associate claimant was the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and perceived to be wealthy. They further allege that the armed group has threatened them on multiple occasions.
[4] The claimants allege that the armed group will kill them if they return to Colombia because they failed to accede to the requests for extortion.
DETERMINATION
[5] I find that the claimants are not Convention refugees as they do not have a well-founded fear of persecution related to a Convention ground in Colombia. I also find that the claimants are not persons in need of protection in that their removal to Colombia would not subject them personally to a risk to life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment. There are also no substantial grounds to believe that the removal of the claimants to Colombia would subject them personally to a danger of torture.
ANALYSIS
Identity
[6] I find that the claimants' identities as nationals of Colombia have been established by the testimony of the associate and principal claimants and the supporting documentation filed, including their passports.2
Credibility
[7] When a claimant swears to the truth of their allegations, this creates a presumption that those allegations are true, unless there is reason to doubt their truthfulness. In this case, I find the claimants to be generally credible with respect to the allegations they have made. Both the principal and the associate claimant answered the questions that were posed to them in a detailed manner and seemed to be forthright when recounting the steps that the armed group had taken to extort them.
[8] In addition, the claimants have disclosed a number of documents which corroborate their allegations, including:
* Copies of threatening letters which were delivered to their home.3
* A copy of a report and order issued by the Attorney General and a police report made in XXXX on XXXX XXXX, 2019 which corroborates that the associate claimant received a threatening phone call from a member of a "new group from XXXX," that the new criminal group needed financial support, and that if the claimants would not cooperate with them they would kill them.4
* Written security standards provided by the police in XXXX to the associate claimant as a result of the police complaint that he made, which list steps he can take to keep himself safe.5
* A letter from the associate claimant's parents which corroborates some of the allegations made by the claimants.6
[9] Although there were no material inconsistencies during their testimony, the claimants did contradict themselves when speaking about the risks that they face in Colombia. In particular, the associate claimant indicated at one point that the claimants had "made every effort not to have contact with anyone from Colombia" so that the armed group would not know their whereabouts. When asked how he had obtained a letter of support from his parents for the purposes of this hearing, he revised his statement to say that he had been in contact with his wife's family members and with an employee of the XXXX. While I do accept the allegations that the claimants have made, I do not accept their characterization of the risks that they face in Colombia or the reach of the agent of harm.
Nexus
[10] In this case, I find that there is no nexus between the claimants' allegations and a Convention ground. In other words, the claimants do not fear harm on the basis of their race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group. Rather, the claimants fear a threat to their personal safety by an armed group that operates in XXXX. As the claimants' fear is based on criminality, section 96 of the Act does not apply. This claim is therefore assessed under section 97 of the Act.
Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
[11] The determinative issue for this claim is the existence of an IFA. In this case, the claimants were provided with notice of Cartagena as a potential IFA at the outset of the hearing.
[12] The definition of a "person in need of protection" in the Act requires that a claimant show that any risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment would be faced "in every part of [a claimant's] country." Similarly, a claimant must show that he or she cannot escape a danger of torture through internal relocation. In order to determine whether the claimants have met this requirement, the following two prong test applies:
1. The Board must be satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the claimants would not be personally subject to a risk to life or risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or a danger, believed on substantial grounds to exist, of torture in the IFA; and
2. The Board must be satisfied that the conditions in the part of the country considered to be an IFA must be such that it would not be unreasonable in all the circumstances, including those particular to the claimants, for them to seek refuge there.
[13] Both prongs must be satisfied to find that the claimants have a viable IFA and, as with establishing the claim more generally, once the issue has been raised by the panel the burden in establishing a lack of an IFA lies with the claimants.
First prong of the IFA test: Would the claimant be at risk in the IFA?
[14] In order to assess whether the claimants would face a risk to life, a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment, or a risk of torture in Cartagena, I have considered whether the evidence indicates that the agent of harm has the motivation and means to pursue the claimants in Cartagena. I have also considered whether there are any other risks to the claimants there, other than the harm they fear from the armed group.
The Agent of Harm
[15] In this case, the claimants have alleged that the agent of harm is a criminal armed group that is composed of "FARC dissidents" and that has ties to the ELN. The associate claimant testified that on XXXX XXXX, 2019 he was working at a XXXX owned by his parents in XXXX when he received a phone call from a member of this armed group. That individual identified himself as a "delinquent outside of the law" and a member of "a new group coming into XXXX." This individual told the associate claimant that he had to give him money and that if the associate claimant refused to collaborate financially with him that they would murder him and his wife.
[16] The following day, the associate claimant reported these threats to the Attorney General's office and to the police in XXXX. He was provided with a general list of actions that he could take to ensure his own protection but did not otherwise receive protection from the police.7
[17] The associate claimant received a second phone call from the armed group on XXXX XXXX. He testified that he hung up the phone as soon as the caller identified himself and asked him where the money was. After this, the associate claimant testified that he made the decision to no longer accept any phone calls directed from the XXXX's landline.
[18] On XXXX XXXX, the claimants received a threatening letter. The letter had been slipped under the door of their home and reads: "Remember that the life of your daughter is worth more. Cooperation is not denied to anyone. Cooperate with us, unless you want to see blood spilt."8 The associate claimant testified that he was fearful upon receiving the threatening letter and it was then that the claimants made the decision to leave Colombia.
[19] On XXXX XXXX, members of the armed group accosted the principal and minor claimants when they were near the minor claimant's school in XXXX. The principal claimant testified that the individuals who accosted her told her not to forget to tell her husband to pay "the quota" or they would hurt her daughter. They also told her that the claimants would not be able to avoid them because they had been placed under surveillance. The associate claimant testified that following this incident, the principal claimant no longer went to work and the minor claimant no longer went to school.
[20] The associate claimant testified that he was also accosted by the armed group on XXXX XXXX in XXXX. The armed group intercepted him on his motorbike, made him take off his helmet, and put a gun to his head. The group told the associate claimant once again that if he did not meet their extortion demands, then they would kill his wife and daughter. The associate claimant alleges that during this altercation, members of the armed group identified themselves as members of the ELN.
[21] The associate claimant testified that they received a second threatening letter on XXXX XXXX. This letter had also been slipped under the door to their home and reads: "Careful with what you love the most. Do not regret your actions. Cooperate with us."9 The letter is created with letters that have been cut out of newspaper articles and is unsigned.
[22] After the incident that occurred on XXXX XXXX, the associate claimant testified that he became really scared and decided to delegate all of his functions at the XXXX to other staff members. He indicated that both he, the principal and the minor claimants decided to shut themselves in their house. The associate claimant did not go back to the XXXX as of XXXX XXXX.
[23] The claimants left XXXX on XXXX XXXX and departed from Colombia on XXXX XXXX, 2019.
Motivation of Agent of Harm
[24] In this case, there is insufficient evidence that the agent of harm would have the motivation to track the claimants to another city. When I asked the associate claimant whether the armed group would be able to find him in Cartagena or anywhere else in Colombia he replied that the armed group has "a lot of infiltrated people throughout the whole of Colombia", that they would continue to seek him out because he "did not comply with what they were demanding," and that armed groups always seek out people with economic means and that "once they target you they do not release you and follow it through until the very end." Likewise, the principal claimant also testified that "all those people are infiltrated" and "they have political clout" and indicated that the armed group would continue to look for them "because we did not acquiesce to their demands." The claimants have offered no concrete evidence to support these assertions and I find them speculative.
[25] On numerous occasions throughout his testimony, the associate claimant explained that the armed group had decided to target him because of his affiliation with the XXXX and the perception that he is wealthy. He also testified that during the phone calls he received from the armed group, as well as during the violent incidents that occurred on XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX, the armed group referenced the money that they felt was owed to them. I find that the primary motivation of the armed group was extortion and that this makes it unlikely that the armed group would search for the claimants outside of XXXX, as there are numerous other businesses and individuals they could extort within closer proximity.
[26] When questioned by his counsel, the associate claimant further specified that the armed group would also have the motivation to search for him because he is a high-profile person in Colombia. He explained that his mother had previously been a XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX. The claimant did not provide any further evidence about his mother's XXXX activities, and so although I accept that his mother was involved in XXXX to some extent in XXXX, I have insufficient evidence to establish that this would put the associate claimant at risk in Cartagena. In response to a question from his counsel, the associate claimant also indicated that his family is well known throughout Colombia because the XXXX is very popular and has been run by his family for more than 50 years. He indicated that his parents are well-known in Colombia because XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. However, I have insufficient evidence to establish that the associate claimant's affiliation with a popular XXXX would put him at risk throughout the country.
[27] In addition to the above, there is no indication that the armed group has launched a search for the claimants outside of XXXX. The associate claimant testified that one of his employees has told him that members of the armed group continue to call the XXXX in XXXX in an attempt to locate the associate claimant, but there is no evidence that the armed group has searched for the claimants outside of XXXX or even beyond contacting the XXXX where the associate claimant used to work. The principal claimant has a sister who lives in Cali and there is no indication that the armed group has attempted to contact the principal claimant's sister in order to locate the claimants. I am unable to determine whether the armed group has contacted the associate claimant's parents to continue to look for him, as he testified that he has cut off contact with his parents. However, I do note that associate claimant's parents provided a letter in support of the claimants' refugee application, which was received by the principal claimant on XXXX XXXX, 2020, and that this letter does not indicate that the armed group has contacted the associate claimant's parents to look for him.10
[28] A refugee assessment is forward-looking. Assessing the above factors cumulatively, I conclude that the claimants have not established on a balance of probabilities that the agent of harm is sufficiently motivated to locate them in Cartagena.
The Means of the Agent of Harm
[29] Further, even if motivated to do so, I find that there is insufficient evidence before me to establish that the agent of harm would be able to locate the claimants in Cartagena.
[30] The claimants testified that the agent of harm is affiliated with the ELN and that no place in Colombia is safe from the ELN. I acknowledge the objective evidence before me establishing that armed criminal groups operate throughout the country and that the ELN in particular seems to have expanded its areas of operations due to a vacuum left by the FARC peace process. The ELN is described as one of the larger criminal groups in the country and commits crimes and acts of terror in many different areas of the country.11 One source in the National Documentation Package indicates that ELN groups are in constant dialogue and can monitor a target across the country.12 As such, I acknowledge that if sufficiently motivated, the ELN may have the capacity to track someone in a different location.
[31] However, I disagree with the claimants' characterization of the agent of harm and their affiliation with the ELN. I have insufficient evidence before me to conclude that the armed individuals who were threatening the claimants have a significant position with the ELN. This is significant because it has direct bearing on the capacity of the armed group to locate the claimants in another city.
[32] The associate claimant testified that he knows that the armed group is affiliated with the ELN because it is "common knowledge" but also testified that when the armed group initiated contact they described themselves as a "new group coming into XXXX." When making the police report, the associate claimant described the group as a "new group from XXXX, Tolima" that "needed financial support."13 Likewise, the claimants disclosed a news article which points to the rising crime rate in XXXX and which attributes this to "criminal gangs" operating in the area and targeting vulnerable sectors of the city. The article does not indicate that the ELN is responsible for any of these crimes.14 The claimants have also disclosed additional country condition evidence about the ELN, but these articles do not provide proof that the ELN is the armed group that is targeting the claimants.15
[33] The associate claimant testified that the armed group identified itself as affiliated with the ELN only once, during the altercation which occurred on XXXX XXXX, 2019. At this point, the armed group had contacted the claimants twice over the phone, had written one threatening letter, and had threatened the associate claimant and the minor claimant in person in order to convince the claimants to give into their extortion demands. Given these circumstances, I do not find there is sufficient evidence to tie the armed group to the ELN and find that it was just as likely that the armed gang referenced the ELN during the altercation in order to cause the claimants to become fearful and take their threats seriously.
[34] The associate claimant also alleged that the armed group targeting his family has ties to the FARC. When asked how he knew the group was affiliated with the FARC, he indicated that "it's the same organization in the end." He did not provide any proof that the armed group has links to the FARC and, based on his testimony, the group has never identified itself as aligned with the FARC. The police report that has been disclosed also does not indicate that the associate claimant identified the group as affiliated with the FARC or that the police viewed the group as affiliated with the FARC. Although the claimant has provided country condition evidence which indicates that the FARC are "resuming their war against Colombia after having demobilized under the 2016 peace agreement" and are building alliances with the ELN, there is no indication that the armed group that has threatened the claimants is related to the FARC.16 I therefore find that any allegation that the armed group is aligned with or has ties with the FARC is speculative.
[35] There is insufficient evidence to establish that the members of the armed group that targeted the claimants are high-level members of the ELN or the FARC who have any level of influence or power. Given the evidence that is before me, I find it is speculative to suggest that the armed group that targeted the claimants would have the connections or the resources to locate the claimants throughout Colombia.
[36] For all these reasons, I conclude that the claimants have not established on a balance of probabilities that the agent of harm has the means to locate them in Cartagena.
Conclusion on the First Prong of the IFA Test
[37] Based on the evidence before me, I find that there is insufficient evidence that the agent of harm would have the motivation or means to pursue the claimants if they were to relocate within Colombia. I thus find on a balance of probabilities that the claimants would not be personally subject to a section 97 risk in Cartagena.
Second Prong of the IFA Test: Reasonableness of the IFA
[38] With respect to the second prong of the IFA test, I find on a balance of probabilities that the claimants' lives or safety would not be jeopardized by traveling to or living in Cartagena and that it would not be unreasonable, given all the circumstances, including those particular to the claimants, to expect the claimants to relocate to this city.17
[39] When asked if there was any other reason the claimants could not relocate to Cartagena, the claimants indicated that they would not feel safe anywhere in Colombia. I accept that armed criminal groups have a profound impact on security in Colombia. However, sources have assessed Cartagena as being only a "medium-threat" location for crime and have indicated that Cartagena shares many of the same crime problems that plague large cities around the world, and that the most common types of crimes include muggings, assaults, cell phone theft, credit card fraud, and burglaries.18 Sources further indicate that Colombia's two most prominent terrorist organizations, the ELN and the FARC, do not have a significant presence in Cartagena.19 While violent crime does occur in Cartagena, it does not occur at such a level as to render the IFA unreasonable.
[40] I also find that relocation to Cartagena is reasonable in the claimants' particular circumstances. Cartagena is a major urban centre in Colombia with over one million inhabitants.20 Both of the adult claimants are educated. The associate claimant is trained as a XXXX XXXX and as a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and has completed XXXX XXXX towards his XXXX XXXX. The principal claimant is a XXXX XXXX with experience working in XXXX and has completed XXXX XXXX towards an XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. Given the urban nature of Cartagena and the claimants' qualifications and work experience, I find that it is likely that the adult claimants would be able to find work and sustain themselves in Cartagena. As the minor claimant would relocate with her parents, I further find that she would have the support necessary to establish a life in Cartagena. I acknowledge that relocating to Cartagena may be difficult given the claimants' lack of connection to the city, but there is no evidence that the conditions would be unduly harsh such that they would render the IFA unreasonable.
Conclusion on the Second Prong of the IFA Test
[41] In sum, I have considered the conditions in Cartagena and all the circumstances of the case, including the personal situation of the claimants. I have considered the documentary evidence and the country conditions in Colombia. Based on all the evidence before me, I find that the claimants have not established that their lives or safety would be jeopardized upon relocating to Cartagena. Accordingly, I find that the claimants have an IFA in Cartagena.
CONCLUSION
[42] I conclude that the claimants are neither Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection and I reject their claims.
(signed)

REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX, the claimants, seek protection in Canada pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1
[2] Rule 55(1) of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) Rules mandates that where claimants have certain specified relationships, such as spouses or parent and child, their claims are to be joined.2 The claimants are spouses, thus their claims are being heard jointly.
BACKGROUND
[3] The claimants allege a well-founded fear of persecution in Hungary by reason of their Roma ethnicity.3 They identify the agents of persecution as Hungarian Guards, skinheads, and persons who are hostile and aggressive towards Roma in general. They are reluctant to return to Hungary because, in their view, there is an increasing degree of discrimination in all walks of life including education, housing and employment.
[4] In addition, they allege the following specific incidents of discrimination:
* 2007 - the male claimant and his friends were refused entry into a nightclub because they were Roma;
* XXXX 2009 - the claimants' fence was destroyed. It was the only one in the neighbourhood that was destroyed. They were the only Roma family in the neighbourhood;
* XXXX 2009 - three Hungarian Guards in a black car confronted the male claimant. The attack was unprovoked. The three men beat the male claimant. They also threaten to harm or kill him. The male claimant managed to flee the scene, but could hear the men uttering death threats against his family as he fled;
* XXXX 2009 - a week later an attempt was made to invade the claimant's home;
* XXXX 2010 - two Hungarian Guards attacked the male claimant as he was returning home from the store. He fled;
* 2000 - 2010 - the claimants were forced to move six times because of discrimination and harassment; and
* XXXX 2010 - the landlord evicted the family because the neighbours objected to living next to Roma persons.
[5] The claimants also allege that after the male claimant left Hungary and came to Canada, two men attacked, insulted and beat the female claimant. Meanwhile, their daughter fell victim to discrimination at school. Not only was she excluded from full participation in her classes, she was beaten up.
IDENTITY
[6] On the basis of the certified copies of the claimant's Hungarian passports, the panel finds that their identities have been satisfactorily established.4
PRELIMINARY MATTERS
[7] Initially, the Minister indicated that he intended to intervene in the hearing of the claims. On June 14, 2012, Counsel for the Minister served the Refugee Protection Division with a Notice to Intervene.5 Counsel for the Minister alleged that the male claimant was wanted in Hungary for the crime of "aggravated fraud."6 Counsel for the Minister argued that, pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Convention on the Status of Refugees (Refugee Convention),7 and section 98 of the IRPA,8 the male claimant was potentially excluded from Convention refugee protection.
[8] These provisions provide that persons who have committed serious non-political crimes prior to entry into Canada are excluded from Convention refugee protection. Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention reads as follows:
F. The provisions of the Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that:
[...]
b) he has committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to his admission to that country as a refugee...9
[9] Section 98 of the IRPA states:
98 A person referred to in section E or F of Article 1 of the Refugee Convention is not a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection.10
[10] The Minister also signalled his intention to intervene on the basis that the claimants' credibility was impugned because they did not disclose the fact of their Hungarian convictions at the time they made their claims for refugee protection. Subsequently, Counsel for the Minister altered his position. He withdrew his intervention regarding exclusion, but maintained his position with respect to his credibility objections.11
[11] The Minister participated in the hearing by means of documents only, and did not appear in person.
[12] Notwithstanding the Minister's withdrawal of his intervention on the basis that the male claimant is excluded from Convention refugee protection for the commission of a serious non-political crime, the panel found that it remained incumbent upon it to determine whether the male claimant was inadmissible to Canada. The panel places reliance for its position in the statements made by Justice Gleason.
[13] In Ospina Velasquez, Justice Gleason was considering a similar question, namely whether the Board erred in finding that the claimant was inadmissible under Article 1F(b) of the Convention even though the Minister had not intervened.12 The claimant did not dispute the Board's jurisdiction to inquire into exclusion on its own motion, given the duty and role of the Board under the IRPA. Instead, he claimed that the Board did not give adequate weight to the fact the Minister had chosen not to intervene, which is similar to the Minister's position in this claim.
[14] In rejecting the claimant's argument, Justice Gleason stated that the Board is not bound to accept the position of a party in any case and, instead, is required to carry out its statutory duty of applying the IRPA. To wit "Second and more fundamentally, the Board is not bound to accept the position of a party in any case and instead is required to carry out its statutory duty of applying the IRPA"13 He stated at paragraph 15 of the decision that under the IRPA, the "RPD's role is an inquisitorial one."14 Justice Gleason also referred to the Board Chairperson's Guideline 7: Concerning Preparation and Conduct of a Hearing in the Refugee Protection Division, which gives RPD Members powers equivalent to those of commissioners.15
[15] In Nwobi, Mr. Justice Martineau discussed the Board's role in determining whether a person is inadmissible under Article 1F(b) of the Convention, noting that it is distinct from that of a judge, and that the Board can inquire into exclusion of its own motion.16 Citing Justice Gleason's statements in Ospina Velasquez, Martineau, J. stated that the Board is duty bound to consider all grounds, including grounds that had not been raised by the parties. The panel also looks to the statements of the Federal Court of Appeal in Arica, where the Court unequivocally stated:
The fact that the Minister does not participate in the hearing, either because he does not wish to do so or because he is not entitled to notice under rule 9(3), does not alter the right of the Board to render a decision on the issue of exclusion.17
[16] Moreover, in Alwan, the Court concluded that since the RPD has "sole and exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine all questions of law and fact, including questions of jurisdiction," non-participation of the Minister does not preclude an exclusion finding.18 Accordingly, the panel proceeded to hear evidence on the issue of exclusion under Article 1F(b) and section 98 of the IRPA.
ISSUES
[17] The issues that arise for determination are:
* whether the male claimant excluded from Convention refugee protection pursuant to Article 1F(b) and section 98 of the IPRA; and
* the credibility of the claimant's allegations of persecution.
DETERMINATION
[18] The panel determines that, pursuant to Article 1F(b) and section 98 of the IRPA, the male claimant is excluded from refugee protection.
[19] The panel determines that the female claimant is not a Convention refugee, and is not a person in need of protection.
Are there serious reasons for considering that the male claimant has committed a serious non-political crime?
[20] The evidence reveals that, as an adult, the male claimant was charged a number of offences, including the criminal offences that relate to the Minister's intervention.19 An Interpol Warrant alleges that he is wanted in relation to "aggravated fraud."20
* 1 count of persistent fraud with incitement as per paragraph 318(1), Section (2), Point c.) and Section (5) Subsection B.) of the Criminal Penal Code [Hungary]
* 5 counts of persistent fraud with incitement as per Paragraph 318, Section (1) Subsection c.), and Section (5), subsection b.) of the Criminal Penal Code [Hungary]
* 1 count of criminal fraud as per Paragraph 318, Section (1) and (2), (5) Subsection b.), as well as Paragraph 16 of the Criminal Penal Code [Hungary]
* 1 count of criminal fraud as per Paragraph 318. Section (1) and (2) Section (4), Subsection b.) of the Criminal Penal Code [Hungary]
* 11 counts of document forgery as per Paragraph 276 (Indictment section 1,2,34,6,7,8,9,10,14,16) of the Criminal Penal Code [Hungary]
* 1 count of document forgery as per paragraph 276 (indictment section 15) of the Criminal Penal Code [Hungary].21
[21] In his initial submissions, the Minister argued that the male claimant violated sections 328 and 318 of the Hungarian Penal Code:
Section 318
(1) The person who - for unlawful profit-making - leads somebody into error or keeps in error and causes damage thereby, commits fraud.
(2) The punishment shall be for a misdemeanor imprisonment of up to two years, labour in the public interest, or fine, if the fraud causes a smaller damage, or the fraud not exceeding the value limit for minor offence is committed
a) as part of a criminal conspiracy,
b) on the scene of public danger,
c) in a business-like manner.
(4) The punishment shall be for a felony imprisonment of up to three years, if
a) the fraud causes a greater damage,
b) the fraud causing a smaller damage is committed in the manner defined in subsection (2), paragraphs a) to c).
(5) The punishment shall be imprisonment from one year to five years, if
a) the fraud causes considerable damage,
b) the fraud causing greater damage is committed in the manner defined in subsection (2), paragraphs a) to c).Subsection (2).
(6) The punishment shall be imprisonment from two years to eight years, if
a) the fraud causes an especially great damage,
b) the fraud causing a considerable damage is committed in the manner defined in subsection (2), paragraphs a) to c).
(7) The punishment shall be imprisonment between five to ten years for the crime of fraud if committed
a) causing particularly substantial damage
b) causing particularly considerable damage in the manner described in Paragraphs a)-c) of Subsection (2) above,
c) as part of a criminal organization.22
[22] Counsel for the Minister submitted that these sections of the Hungarian Criminal Code are equivalent to section 380(1) of the Criminal Code of Canada (CCC), which addresses the crime of fraud.23 The section provides:
380 (1) Everyone who, by deceit, falsehood or other fraudulent means, whether or not it is a false pretence within the meaning of this Act, defrauds the public or any person, whether ascertained or not, of any property, money or valuable security or any service,
(a) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to a term of imprisonment not exceeding fourteen years, where the subject-matter of the offence is a testamentary instrument or the value of the subject-matter of the offence exceeds five thousand dollars...24
[23] Both provisions address the crime of fraud. They describe the circumstances when the crime of fraud would be considered to have been committed under the respective law. Thus, under the Hungarian law, the following elements are required:
* the intent to make an unlawful profit;
* the inducement of an error by a third person, linked to the unlawful profit or the maintaining of that person in his or her error; and
* damage.
[24] The Canadian law requires that there be:
* deceit;
* a fraudulent act; and
* damage.
[25] The panel is of the view that the elements of the crime described in both legislative schemes are sufficiently similar, as to speak to the same or similar crime(s). The panel finds that the crime of fraud described by section 318 of the Hungarian Penal Code is equivalent to the crime of fraud described in the CCC.
[26] The male claimant was charged with and convicted of seven counts of fraud. The panel is satisfied that had the male claimant committed these crimes in Canada, he would have been charged with fraud as set out in section 380 of the CCC. The panel finds that, as initially argued by Counsel for the Minister, had the male claimant committed the alleged crimes in Canada, he could have received the maximum penalty of ten years, and thus under Article 1F(b), he would have been excluded from refugee protection.
Did the male claimant commit a serious non-political crime?
[27] Much of the case law is given over to defining what is meant by 'serious reasons for considering' as well as 'non-political crime.' In Ezokola, the Supreme Court of Canada (SCC) equates 'serious reasons for considering' to 'less than the balance of probabilities' but more than mere suspicion or conjecture.25
[28] The Federal Court of Appeal has stated that 'serious non-political crime' refers to "ordinary crimes which are recognised by traditional criminal law."26 However, the Court has also made it clear that economic crimes are not excluded, as a claimant may be excluded for purely economic crimes.27 This is important because the male claimant's crimes that are the subject of this proceeding are crimes of an economic nature.
[29] It has not been advanced that the crimes of which the male claimant was convicted were political crimes. The panel finds that they were patently non-political crimes.
[30] The Minister withdrew his exclusion intervention on the basis that the male claimant's "offences do not meet the threshold of seriousness for purpose of Article 1F(b)."28 The Minister argued that as the male claimant likely would not have received the maximum penalties for his offences, and, in fact, received sentences of between two to three years. It is indicated that the sentences would not be considered serious enough for exclusion.
[31] The panel disagrees with the Minister's reasoning. The panel is of the view that it is the potential penalty, as opposed to the actual sentence received, that is determinative of the threshold for seriousness. The panel relies on the decision in Febles for its position.29 In Febles, Chief Justice McLachlin, who rendered the opinion of the majority of the SCC, stated that she was in agreement with the decisions of the Federal Court of Appeal (FCA) in Chan30 and Jayasekara.31 In those cases, the FCA has taken the view that where a maximum sentence of ten years or more could have been imposed had the crime been committed in Canada, the crime will generally be considered serious.
[32] Section 380 of the CCC imposes a maximum penalty of ten years for the crime of fraud. According to his Hungarian Attorney-at-Law, Gabor Kelenyi, the male claimant was found guilty of seven counts of fraud and seven counts of document forgery.32 In light of the maximum penalty contained in section 380, the panel finds that the male claimant's fraud convictions are prima facie convictions for serious crimes.
[33] Furthermore, the male claimant testified that he pled guilty to the charges. A plea of guilty to a charge constitutes a sound basis for a finding that there are serious reasons for considering that the male claimant has committed a serious non-political crime.33 In reaching its determination as to whether there are serious reasons for considering that the male claimant has committed a serious non-political crime in Hungary prior to coming to Canada, the panel considered the cumulative effect of the indictment, the male claimant's admissions as to his convictions, and his plea of guilty. Taking all of this information into consideration, the panel finds that there are serious reasons for considering that he did.
Ought the male claimant to be excluded from refugee protection?
[34] In Febles, Chief Justice McLachlin writing for the majority, indicated that while a ten-year maximum penalty would normally give rise to a presumption that the crime in question is a serious crime, it was a rebuttable presumption:
...this generalization should not be understood as a rigid presumption that is impossible to rebut. Where a provision of the Canadian Criminal Code, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-46, has a large sentencing range, the upper end being ten years or more and the lower end being quite low, a claimant whose crime would fall at the less serious end of the range in Canada should not be presumptively excluded. ... the presumption may be rebutted in a particular case. While consideration of whether a maximum sentence of ten years or more could have been imposed had the crime been committed in Canada is a useful guideline, and crimes attracting a maximum sentence of ten years or more in Canada will generally be sufficiently serious to warrant exclusion, the ten-year rule should not be applied in a mechanistic, decontextualized, or unjust manner.34
[35] Jayasekara provides a road map by which panels are to be guided in their determination of whether to exclude a claimant from refugee protection pursuant to Article 1F(b) and section 98 of the IRPA.35 It was held that, with respect to Article 1F(b) when determining whether or not a crime is to be considered 'serious' for the purpose of exclusion, panels should evaluate the following factors: "the elements of the crime, the mode of prosecution, the penalty prescribed, the facts, and the mitigating and aggravating circumstances underlying the conviction."36
The elements of the crime
[36] The relevant legislative provisions have been discussed above and found to be substantially similar in both pieces of legislation. The male claimant testified that the fraudulent activity involved fraudulent credit applications for loans, consumer goods, and used cars. The persons applying for the loans and credit were all Roma. In some instances, they passed the receipts, either in whole or in part, back to the male claimant. He alleged that the salesmen in the car dealerships were aware of and participated in the fraudulent activity by providing paperwork for the fraudulent car loans.
[37] Section 374 of the CCC addresses forgery and offences resembling forgery.37 The section makes them indictable offences that carry a maximum prescribed penalty upon conviction of fourteen years. Section 375 of the CCC is also relevant:
Everyone who demands, receives or obtains anything, or causes or procures anything to be delivered or paid to any person under, on or by virtue of any instrument issued under the authority of law, knowing that it is based on a forged document, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.38
The mode of prosecution and the prescribed penalties
[38] Accord to the indictment, the male claimant was charged with twelve counts of document forgery, his Attorney-at-Law states that he was convicted on twelve counts and found guilty of a lesser offence in respect of the other five counts.39 At least five of the male claimant's fraud charges were laid under section 318(5) of the Hungarian Law, which not only attracts a higher penalty, but acknowledges that the frauds were carried out as part of a Criminal conspiracy, on the scene of public danger or, what the Hungarian Law describes as a 'business-like' manner.40 As stated earlier, the male claimant admitted that the frauds were carried out in respect of commercial ventures.
[39] The male claimant was also charged with twelve counts of uttering forged documents. These charges proceeded on indictment, 41 indicating, on its face, that the Hungarian Law, clearly viewed these offences as serious offences.
[40] Section 318 of the Hungarian law prescribes a range of penalties depending on the value of the good, the extent of the frauds and the manner in which they are committed, while no such range attached to section 380 of the CCC. However, as the male claimant did not receive a sentence below two years of imprisonment, the panel infers that his offences were treated as felonies and not misdemeanours, and punished accordingly.
The facts
[41] The indictment states that the male claimant was involved in fraudulent activity that affected banks, grocery stores, electronic stores, and car dealerships.42 The amounts ranged from XXXX XXXX XXXXto XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Hungarian forints. It also alleged that if it were not for the fact that some institutions denied credit, the frauds would have been greater.
[42] In a letter addressed to the female claimant, XXXX XXXX provided the following description of the outcome of the male claimant's criminal trial:
... several defendants (altogether 7) and criminal acts (altogether 20) had been tried during this criminal trial. The latter ones were relatively minor private-document-forgery offences (altogether 12). Of these five offences the Court did not find XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX responsible for the offense, but rather found that he played a role as person who was aiding and abetting. Further the Court found that my client, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was responsible in 1 count of fraud, and it remained as such that monetary damage was not inflicted with relation to the crime.
The Court found XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX criminally liable for the remaining offences. One of the victims was "XXXX XXXX XXXX" (Zrt=Incorporation - Translator). The total sum of the financial damage was: XXXX XXXX XXXX Forints.
The victim of the other offense was "XXXX XXXX XXXX" and the financial damage was XXXX XXXX XXXX Forints. The total sum of these 2 offenses is XXXX XXXX XXXX Forints (=$XXXX CDN).43
[43] XXXX XXXX XXXX goes on to state that the male claimant was the only defendant who appealed the convictions. He writes "[u]pon our application the County Court of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX had modified the sentence in the first instance, in that the Court found XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX as a person who was only aiding and abetting in the offense."44
[44] At the hearing, the male claimant did not contest the facts of the frauds as set out in the indictment that was before the Hungarian Court.45 He amplified the circumstances of the charges. He stated that that, contrary to what was stated in the indictment, the criminal conduct spanned not three months but a period of three to four years, during which he purchased seven second-hand motor vehicles, three for himself and four for other persons. He stated when he made the purchases, he was either not employed or not employed in a steady job that would have allowed him to qualify for the credit purchases. However, using falsified documents, mainly employment documents, he was able to obtain the necessary credit. He testified that these forged documents were prepared by employees of the dealerships from which he purchased the cars and that he actually did make some of the instalment payments. All of the vehicles have been repossessed.
[45] The male claimant also admitted that he assisted Roma clients, including family and friends, to obtain goods and loans using false documents. Usually, these documents either inflated the applicant's income or claimed that he or she was employed, enabling the applicant to obtain loans, credit or goods, mainly used cars. The male claimant benefitted from the scheme in that he received a 'kickback' from each client.
[46] The letter from the male claimant's Hungarian attorney indicates that he was found guilty of the lesser crime of aiding and abetting document forgery in five instances, and was found guilty of one count of fraud that involved no monetary damage. As the male claimant was found guilty of the remaining counts, it means that he was found guilty of seven counts of fraud and seven counts of document forgery.
Mitigating and aggravating circumstances underlying the convictions
[47] Counsel for the claimants submits the following as mitigating factors:
* the male claimant's Roma identity;
* that the claimant was scapegoated and received a harsher penalty because he is Roma;
* the fact that the crimes were financial in nature;
* the crimes did not involve violence of any kind; and
* the amounts involved were not overly significant.46
[48] The male claimant's Roma ethnicity was also put forward as a further mitigating circumstance.47 He testified that he was dealt with more harshly because he is ethnically Roma. In his affidavit, XXXX XXXX, claims that while the actual trial was properly conducted, the Hungarian police were negligent in their investigation, with the result that the male claimant's convictions were unjust. XXXX XXXX, attests to his belief that the investigation focused improperly on the male claimant because he was Roma. He was of the view that the police ought to have also investigated the employees of the various banks that had been defrauded.
[49] For the following reasons, the panel finds that the rationales put forward by the male claimant, his counsel, and by XXXX XXXX do not provide satisfactory mitigating factors:
* while it is true that the crimes for which the male claimant was convicted were financial in nature and that they did not involve violence, it is largely acknowledged that financial crimes are not victimless. In this case, the victims were commercial enterprises and potentially the Hungarian consumer. Furthermore, in Xie, the Court decided that a claimant can be excluded from refugee protection for economic reasons;48
* the male claimant testified that he was at all times aware that he was engaging in a fraudulent enterprise;
* the male claimant benefitted from the scheme;
* the male claimant was not forced to participate in the scheme, that is, he was acting willingly;
* the scheme, while relatively simple, involved the use of forged employment and retirement documents that overstated the applicants' income and misstated the source of that income. The sole intent of the scheme was to obtain goods and moneys fraudulently; and
* the male claimant sought to minimise the effect of the frauds by relying on the fact that the commercial enterprises did not participate in the trial. The panel finds that this indicates that he is not remorseful.
[50] The panel is also not persuaded by the argument that the male claimant was dealt with more harshly because of his Roma ethnicity. XXXX XXXX offers his opinion that the male claimant "was convicted for a crime that was undisclosed in its entirety by the Police and the Attorney General's Office, which may only have been in court for discriminative reasons, since he is Roma."49
[51] On the strength of the documentary evidence, the panel is prepared to accept that Roma offenders, as part of a minority that experiences societal discrimination generally, may experience additional difficulties in their interactions with the Hungarian justice system.50 However, there is no independent evidence before the panel that could lead it to conclude that the male claimant was singled out for a harsher penalty. In fact, XXXX XXXX letter indicates that the male claimant appears to have been dealt with fairly, in that, on five counts he was found guilty of a lesser offence. In addition, he was able to appeal and had his original sentence shortened. Further, what is not revealed in the indictment is the extent of the fraud. At the hearing, it came out that the male claimant had been implicated in more than thirty transactions. Both he and the female claimant admitting that they assisted some thirty persons to obtain cars.
[52] On his guilty plea, the male claimant was found guilty of the remaining fourteen offences. His total sentence was two years and eight months.51 The male claimant could have received a maximum penalty of five years under the Hungarian law for at least one of the offences, namely, one count of criminal fraud as per paragraph 318, Section (1) and (2, (5) Subsection b.). Given the number of counts for which he was found guilty, the panel is not persuaded that the male claimant was not dealt with leniently or that the penalty was increased due to his ethnicity.
[53] In the absence of objective evidence to establish the facts of negligence or malice on the part of the police, the panel is also not persuaded by XXXX XXXX claims regarding the actions of the Hungarian police. According to the male claimant he conducted business with the car dealerships, therefore, it is not clear to the panel how the bank's employees were to be charged as accessories to the male claimant's frauds.
[54] Further, XXXX XXXX did set out any objective facts on which he based his opinion. Accordingly, the panel finds that his opinion of the police investigation is simply that of a paid advocate with his theory of the case.
[55] Furthermore, while XXXX XXXX takes the position that the male claimant's involvement in the frauds was minimal, that was not the claimant's testimony. He admitted being an active participant. The panel finds that, in these circumstances, the male claimant's Roma ethnicity is not a mitigating factor.
[56] The panel does find that the fact that the male claimant pled guilty to the charges is a mitigating factor as his guilty plea rendered the expense of a trial unnecessary.
Aggravating factors
[57] An aggravating factor in the determination is the fact that the male claimant does not take responsibility for his actions. He deflected his involvement in the frauds, which he characterised as minimal. He argued that others should have been charged along with him. He stated that he was not the mastermind. He argued that he should have been made to pay a fine. His position is captured in the following sequence of questions and answers:
Qn. You said that you made some 30 referrals to the car dealers? Is that correct?
Ans. Yes.
Qn. And you knew in each instance that fraudulent documents were being used?
Ans. Yes.
Qn. In respect to the shops, is it the same number of referrals?
Ans. Fewer.
Qn. And, again, you knew that a fraudulent document or documents were being used?
Ans. Yes.
Qn. You told the hearing several times that a Hungarian would not have been prosecuted or would not have received the sentence you got?
Ans. Because that is the way it is. Even my lawyer said to me that it is laughable that they sentenced me to two years.
Qn. When you say "that is the way it is" - please explain. Is that something you believe or something you have proof of?
Ans. I just know that there is great hatred of the gypsies in Hungary.
Qn. And based on that knowledge - that there is great hatred of the gypsies in Hungary - you think that your sentence was wrong?
Ans. Yes, I know that mine was not just.
Qn. Ultimately you did not serve this sentence?
Ans. No.
Qn. And you did not serve it because you came to Canada?
Ans. Yes.
Qn. And when you came to Canada, was it your intention to avoid serving the sentence?
Ans. That, as well as the persecution I feared for me and my family.
[58] The panel finds that the male claimant's statements point to a lack of remorse for his crimes.
[59] At the hearing, the male claimant admitted that he had been charged and convicted of the crimes of which he was accused. In response to the panel, he admitted that he pled guilty to the charges and was sentenced to a term of imprisonment of two years and eight months. He also admitted that he did not serve the sentence. In response to the panel's questions, the male claimant responded that he did not serve the sentence because he considered it to be unjust and, therefore, he fled to Canada. As can be seen from the questions and answers set out above, the male claimant argued that instead of imposing a jail sentence, the Hungarian Court could have imposed a fine. He admitted that he left Hungary to avoid serving the sentence.
[60] The panel finds that leaving Hungary when he did was a deliberate act on the part of the male claimant. Further, the panel finds that in so doing, the male claimant placed himself in the position of being a fugitive from justice.
[61] Counsel for the claimants put forward the argument that the effect of the verdict issued by the Secretary for Penal-Execution of the Court of Law of Miskolc is to vitiate or annul the conviction or, at least, to render it of no effect.52 The panel does not agree. In the panel's view, the verdict only states that the male claimant will not be sent to prison because the limitation period within which the sentence ought to have commenced has passed. It does not erase the fact that the claimant was tried and convicted and sentenced to a term of imprisonment of two years and eight months.
[62] Accordingly, in light of the evidence before it, as well as, the male claimant's testimony that he deliberately came to Canada in order to avoid serving his sentence, the panel finds that the male claimant was a fugitive from Hungarian justice when he arrived in Canada.
[63] In Febles, Chief Justice McLachlin, after reviewing leading cases from several jurisdictions including the United Kingdom and France, cited with approval a decision of the Supreme Court of New Zealand. She noted that:
In Attorney-General (Minister of Immigration) v. Tamil X..., the Supreme Court of New Zealand stated that two purposes underlie Article 1F(b): (1) to prevent fugitives from avoiding punishment for their crimes; and (2) to protect the security of states. The court made clear that the language of Article 1F(b) "cannot... be read as confining exclusion to those who are fugitives from justice"...53 [footnotes omitted]
[64] In keeping with this dicta, the panel finds that as a fugitive from justice, Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention applies to the male claimant, XXXX XXXX. Therefore, he is excluded from the Convention refugee protection.
[65] Having found that the male claimant is excluded from Convention refugee protection, the panel finds that in keeping with the decision in Xie, it is not necessary to address the inclusion aspect of the claim.
The female claimant
[66] The female claimant relied on the allegations of persecution that the male claimant set out in his narrative. At the hearing, she adopted his testimony. She, too, was charged with and convicted of fraud. The specific charges were:
* 2 counts of fraud as per Paragraph 318, Section (1) and (4), Subsection a.) (indictment section 11, 12) of the Criminal Code; and
* 2 counts of document forgery as per paragraph 276, (indictment section 11, 12) of the Criminal Code.54
[67] On conviction, the female claimant was sentenced to a term of imprisonment of one year. This was later changed to two years of probation.
[68] In determining whether the female claimant is caught by Article 1F(b), the panel adopts its earlier reasoning regarding what constitutes "serious reasons for considering that a claimant has committed a serious non-political crime prior to coming to Canada."55 On the basis of the indictment, sentence received, and other evidence that was before it, the panel finds that its analysis supports the conclusion that there are not serious reasons for considering that the female claimant committed a serious non-political crime prior to coming to Canada. Accordingly, the panel finds that she is not caught by Article 1F(b), and no question of exclusion arises. The issue to be determined, therefore, is whether the female claimant can credibly establish that there is a serious possibility that she would face persecution in Hungary.
[69] The female claimant alleges that her previous experiences give rise to a well-founded fear of persecution in Hungary. To this she adds that the situation for Roma in Hungary has worsened since she left Hungary. Counsel for the Minister has submitted that the credibility of the female claimant is undermined by her actions in failing to disclose that she had been charged with and convicted of crimes in Hungary. The panel agrees.
[70] In the panel's view by failing to disclose that she had been arrested and charged in circumstances where she clearly knew that she was, the female claimant has exhibited a willingness to mislead Canadian immigration authorities,56 which taints the whole of her evidence. Therefore, while the panel accepts that the female claimant, as a Roma person, likely experienced discrimination and harassment while she was at school, the panel is not persuaded that any discrimination she experienced in Hungary has risen to the level of persecution.
Discrimination while attending school
[71] While the female claimant completed Grade 11 in 1999,57 she complained of discrimination and harassment while she was at school. Based on the documentary evidence that recounts the generally disadvantaged conditions under which Roma children are educated,58 the panel accepts the female claimant's allegations of discrimination and harassment during her school years. Nonetheless, the panel finds that the events of discrimination and harassment are now too remote to constitute persecution.
Discrimination in employment
[72] The female claimant was gainfully employed from the time she left school up to the time she came to Canada.59 Thus, she cannot be said to have been prevented from earning a living. For this reason, the panel finds that any discrimination the female claimant may have experienced in respect of employment has not risen to the level of persecution.
Discrimination in housing
[73] With respect to housing, the female claimant complains that due to anti-Roma discriminatory acts, she was unable to live peaceably in her home. In XXXX 2009, the family's fence was destroyed. She claimed that theirs was the only Roma family in the neighbourhood, and the vandalism was linked to the family's ethnicity. The panel finds this to be speculative because the male claimant testified that, in fact, there was at least one other Roma family living in their neighbourhood.
[74] The claimants alleged that between 2000 and 2010, the family was forced to move more than six times, with them being actually evicted in XXXX 2010. They blamed their necessity to move on anti-Roma discrimination. Both claimants testified that they were forced to move because their white Hungarian neighbours did not want to live next to Roma persons. The panel finds that their allegations are not credible and trustworthy because despite their allegations, the male claimant admitted that he was not actually evicted in XXXX 2010. In fact, the family lived in the home until they came to Canada.
[75] The male claimant testified that the landlord had wanted to evict the family for non-payment of rent, but did not do so because they had young children and could not be evicted during winter. He blamed the non-payment on theft, stating that the person who came to collect the rent stole the payment. Accepting for the moment that one month's rent was in fact stolen, the panel found that this testimony was not credible because when the male claimant was asked about the theft, he testified that it was his practice to pay the rent to the landlord's agent. He did so for some six months. When asked why he did not have receipts for any of the payments, the male claimant responded that he paid the rent to the agent as directed by the landlord.
[76] In circumstances where the claimants allege that they are the victims of anti-Roma discrimination, the panel finds that it is reasonable to expect that they would ask for receipts as proof of payment of rent. In the circumstances, the panel finds that the male claimant's explanation is not satisfactory. The panel finds that the unsatisfactory explanation undermines the allegations that the claimants were forced to move six times because of anti-Roma sentiment. The panel finds, on a balance of probabilities, that the reason the claimants had to move was not related to their Roma identity.
[77] Moreover, if the claimants are to be believed, their testimony and evidence indicates that for at least a decade they lived in predominantly non-Roma neighbourhoods. The panel finds that this fact further undermines their testimony that they were discriminated against in their choice of housing. The panel finds that the claimants have exaggerated their circumstances, and any move between 2000 and 2010 was not due solely to their Roma ethnicity as they alleged.
Attacks against the male claimant
[78] The male claimant alleged that he was the victim of two unprovoked attacks by Hungarian Guards. He testified that in XXXX 2009, three Hungarian Guards in a black car confronted him and threatened to kill him. As he fled, he could hear them threatening to kill his family. He did not testify that they followed him. When asked, the claimant denied knowing the men who attacked him. He testified that about a week later, there was an attempt to invade the family home. He surmised that it was the same persons who attacked him the week before. He testified that he lived in a town with a population of about 600,000, of whom roughly 80,000 were Roma.
[79] The panel finds that this aspect of the principal claimant's testimony is not reliable because it is not plausible that in a town of this size, where the male claimant did not know his attackers and where they did not follow him, they would have known where he lived and try to invade his home. The panel rejects this aspect of the male claimant's testimony.
[80] The male claimant also alleged that shortly before he left Hungary, Hungarian Guards attacked him as he left a store, however, he was able to get away from them.
[81] Counsel for the Minister submitted that the male claimant's failure to disclose his criminal history undermines his credibility. To the extent that the failure demonstrates a willingness to mislead Canadian immigration authorities, the panel agrees. However, even without rejecting his allegations that members of the Hungarian Guard attacked him on two separate occasions, the panel finds that the discrimination the male claimant experienced did not rise to the level of persecution as they lack the element of frequency.
[82] The female claimant relies mainly on the male claimant's story to establish her claim. In light of the panel's finding that the discrimination he experienced has not risen to the level of persecution, the panel makes the same finding about her claim.
Incidents occurring after the male claimant left Hungary
[83] The female claimant alleged that after the male claimant left Hungary and came to Canada, she was attacked and beaten. She also alleged that her child fell victim to discrimination at school. Shee was excluded from full participation in her classes and was beaten up.
[84] The female claimant filed a police report to this effect. She also exhibited a medical report that was taken the day after the alleged report. The panel finds this report to be equivocal. On the one hand it states that there was "no external sign of injury to the female claimant's left face and lower arm' while it also sates that that "left side of her face and lower arm and abdomen bruises." The panel finds that the document is internally inconsistent on its face. Accordingly, the panel gives it little weight when determining the female claimant's allegation that she was beaten up in XXXX 2010. Ultimately, the panel finds that there is insufficient evidence before it to allow a finding that the Hungarian Guards attacked and beat the female claimant.
[85] Their daughter's claim has already been adjudicated and was not before this panel. Therefore, the panel makes no determination regarding the female claimant's fears for her.
STATE PROTECTION
[86] The female claimant alleges that state protection would not be forthcoming to her in Hungary. She relied on the male claimant's testimony that when they called the police in respect to the incident with their fence, the police closed the investigation after two months. The panel finds that this is not sufficient to establish a failure of state protection because it is apparent that the police did respond to the incident and did open an investigation into it.
[87] The panel finds that the female claimant has not displaced the presumption of state protection.
CONCLUSION
[88] The claimants, XXXX XXXXandXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, seek protection in Canada pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA. Based on the above analysis, the panel finds that pursuant to Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, and section 98 of the IRPA, XXXX XXXX is excluded from Convention refugee protection.
[89] The panel also finds that the female claimant is not a Convention refugee, and is not a person in need of protection as defined in sections 96 and 97(1) of the IRPA.
[90] The claims of XXXX XXXXand XXXX XXXX XXXX are rejected.
(signed)
"H. Ross"
