REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] This is the decision in the claim for refugee protection of XXXX XXXX, who claims to be a citizen of China, and is claiming refugee protection pursuant to section 96 and subsection 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).i
ALLEGATIONS
[2] The details of the Claimant's allegations appear in his Basis of Claim (BOC) form and amended narrative under Exhibits 2 and 5 respectively and in his oral testimony. The central allegations of the case appear as follows.
[3] The Claimant and his former common law partner were not able to register their marriage as they had not reached the statutory age for marriage at the time they applied to register their marriage. As a result, they were only able to hold a traditional marriage ceremony.
[4] The Claimant's former common-law wife became pregnant. As this pregnancy was considered out of plan, it is alleged that the Claimant's former common-law wife was forced to undergo an abortion. The Claimant was also arrested, beaten and detained. He also had to pay a monetary fine.
[5] Family planning officials kept on visiting the Claimant and he was fired from his job.
[6] The Claimant eventually left China and came to the United States ("U.S.") in XXXX 2002. He made an asylum claim which was denied. His appeal was likewise denied. He then lived in the U.S. without status and crossed the border to Canada illegally in XXXX 2016.
[7] He was arrested by Canadian police a year later and was detained. He subsequently made a claim for refugee protection.
[8] While living in the U.S., the Claimant was involved in a vehicular accident causing death. Moreover, the Claimant claims that he had been removed from his Household Registry ("Hukou") in China. He also fears the Chinese police if he is to return back to China.
MINISTER'S INTERVENTION
[9] The Minister intervened in person on exclusion under Article 1F(b).ii
DETERMINATION
[10] For the following reasons, the panel finds that there are serious reasons for considering that the Claimant is excludable from protection pursuant to section 98 of the IRPAiii and Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees (Refugee Convention)iv as he committed a serious non-political crime in the U.S., that being the dangerous operation of a conveyance causing death.
ANALYSIS
Identity
[11] On a balance of probabilities, the panel finds that the Claimant is who he says he is and he is a national of China. The Claimant explained the circumstances that led to his failure to provide a passport. In the alternative, the Claimant provided a copy of his old Hukou under Exhibit 7. A notarial birth certificate and a copy of his lost passport under Exhibit 10. He also provided copies of attestations, ID cards from his parents and siblings under the same exhibit.
Exclusion Analysis for the PC
[12] The determinative issue in the analysis for the PC is whether he is excludable under Article 1F(b), which states: "The provisions of this Convention shall not apply to any person with respect to whom there are serious reasons for considering that he has committed a serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge prior to his admission to that country as a refugee."v
[13] Section 98 of the IRPA and Article 1F(b) require the panel to assess whether there are serious reasons for considering that the PC committed a serious non-political crime outside of the country of refuge and prior to admission to Canada. According to the Supreme Court of Canada in Febles v. Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, 2014 SCC 68, [2014] 3 S.C.R. 431, in assessing whether a refugee claimant has "committed a serious non-political crime" the RPD must only focus on the facts and circumstances that existed at the time the crime was committed in assessing whether the crime was serious.vi
[14] The panel must assess whether the crime committed was serious, taking into account the factors outlined in the Federal Court of Appeal decision of Jayasekara v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration), [2009] 4 F.C.R. 164 (F.C.A.); 2008 FCA 404,vii including:
* the nature and elements of the crime
* the mode of prosecution (summary or indictment)
* the penalty prescribed
* the facts surrounding commission of the crime; and
* mitigating and aggravating circumstances underlying the conviction.viii
[15] The Court provided further guidance as to various mitigating and aggravating circumstances that may be considered when determining whether the crime was "serious."ix The Court said that,
[...] a constraint short of the criminal law defense of duress may be a relevant mitigating factor in assessing the seriousness of the crime committed. The harm caused to the victim or society, the use of a weapon, the fact that the crime is committed by an organized criminal group, etc. would also be relevant factors to be considered.x
[16] The IRPA provides for exclusion on the basis of "Serious Criminality" in section 36(1) of the IRPA.
Serious Criminality
36 (1) A permanent resident or a foreign national is inadmissible on grounds of serious criminality for
(a) having been convicted in Canada of an offence under an Act of Parliament punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years, or of an offence under an Act of Parliament for which a term of imprisonment of more than six months has been imposed;
(b) having been convicted of an offence outside Canada that, if committed in Canada, would constitute an offence under an Act of Parliament punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years; or
(c) committing an act outside Canada that is an offence in the place where it was committed and that, if committed in Canada, would constitute an offence under an Act of Parliament punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years.xi
[17] In Dengxii, Justice Hughes stated:
...it was established that an "exclusion" hearing under Article 1F(b) is not in the nature of a criminal trial where guilt or innocence must be proven by the Minister beyond a reasonable doubt. Rather, the onus upon the Minister is to establish, based on the evidence presented to the Board, that there are "serious reasons" for considering...
[18] The panel must be satisfied that the Claimant was responsible for or committed the crime or acts. At the hearing the Claimant testified that he was involved in a vehicular accident in the U.S. The Minister's disclosure under Exhibit 9, provides further elaboration as to the circumstances relating to the fatal accident noted above. The Claimant drove the vehicle involved in the accident, which resulted in a single fatality and the injuries of 18 people. He was charged and a warrant of arrest had been issued for him, when he failed to appear for a hearing into the case. The Claimant denies knowledge of any charges and testified that he was not aware of the hearing in the U.S.
[19] The applicability of the exclusion clause does not depend on whether a Claimant has been charged or convicted of the criminal acts in question. The Minister's burden of proof is merely to demonstrate "serious reasons for considering" that the claimant committed such acts.xiii
[20] The standard of evidence comprised in the phrase serious reasons for considering is well below that required in connection with either the criminal law ("beyond a reasonable doubt") or the civil law ("on a balance of probabilities or preponderance of evidence").xiv
[21] In determining exclusion, the notion of what is to be considered a serious crime is in relation to the criminal law system of the country of refuge, rather than the country of origin.
[22] The Minister is of the opinion that Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention has been raised by this claim on the grounds that the PC has committed a serious non-political crime in the U.S..
[23] The Claimant was involved in a vehicular accident in the U.S, which resulted in one fatality and multiple injuries and damage to vehicles.
[24] Sections 320.13(2) and 320.13(3) of the Criminal Code of Canada ("the Code") creates a hybrid offence, namely, it is an offence that can be prosecuted either by way of indictment or summarily at the election of the crown. Two widely different maximum penalties depending on the whether the offence was prosecuted by indictment or summarily. Hybrid offences, however, in virtue of s. 34 of the Interpretation Act, are deemed indictable unless and until the Crown has elected to proceed summarily, to wit:
Indictable and Summary Offences
* 34 (1) Where an enactment creates an offence,
(a) the offence is deemed to be an indictable offence if the enactment provides that the offender may be prosecuted for the offence by indictment;
(b) the offence is deemed to be one for which the offender is punishable on summary conviction if there is nothing in the context to indicate that the offence is an indictable offence; and
(c) if the offence is one for which the offender may be prosecuted by indictment or for which the offender is punishable on summary conviction, no person shall be considered to have been convicted of an indictable offence by reason only of having been convicted of the offence on summary conviction.xv
[25] As stated earlier a conviction or crime committed outside of Canada is considered serious criminality if it is for an offence that, if committed in Canada, would constitute an offence under an Act of Parliament that is punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least 10 years.xvi This, would make the convicted person inadmissible to Canada.
[26] The panel has also examined the UNHCR handbook regarding the interpretation of the exclusion clauses and has taken into consideration the two following paragraphs:
In evaluating the nature of the crime presumed to have been committed, all relevant factors-including any mitigating circumstances-must be taken into account.xvii
While there is thus a possibility of granting asylum, the gravity of the persecution of which the offender may have in fear, and the extent to which such fear is well founded, will have to be duly considered in determining his possible refugee status under the 1951 Convention.xviii
[27] The panel's analysis of the outlined Jayasekara factors is as follows.xix
Nature and Elements of the Crime:
[28] In assessing whether there are "serious reasons for considering" that the individual committed a serious non-political crime, where a maximum sentence of ten years or more could have been imposed, it is a strong indication that the crime is a serious one.xx
[29] In terms of the punishment in case of death as per Section 320.13(3), a person is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life.
[30] The Claimant argues that what happened was an accident. He testified that he was unable to break his vehicle resulting in him hitting the vehicle in front of him. As a result, this triggered a domino effect which involved a total of four vehicles. In the end, there was one fatality and 18 injuries. The Claimant testified that he was distracted while looking at the highway signs. He was unable to break prior to impact.
[31] The Claimant testified that this occurred in the early evening. The Police summary report included in Exhibit 9, indicate that it was dark at the time of the accident. The Claimant was taken for medical treatment and upon release was arraigned and bailed out and a bond was issued.
[32] Moreover, in Exhibit 9, according to the police investigator's comments, the impact made by the Claimant's vehicle was so severe that the entire rear end of the vehicle it hit was crushed and the rear seat was pushed forward resulting in the fatality. There was no evidence of pre-impact breaking on the part of the Claimant. The Claimant did testify that it was too late for him to break at the point of impact.
The mode of prosecution and the penalty prescribed:
[33] The crime of operation of a conveyance causing bodily harm and operation of a conveyance causing death are hybrid offences. It is worth noting that the police report indicates that the Claimant did not display any signs of intoxication and as such, no probable cause was developed for alcohol or drug testing. He was charged with Operation of a vehicle causing death which was listed as an unclassified misdemeanor.
[34] The Claimant testified that he was not aware of any charges made against him and that he had hired a lawyer to take care of things for him with the assistance of a friend. The Claimant noted that the lawyer looked into the areas of compensation relating to insurance for example.
[35] Given that the Claimant indicated that he was not aware of pending charges against him, he moved to a different jurisdiction and there is no indication that he notified authorities nor his counsel of this. The Claimant testified that he was not aware of such conditions.
[36] According to documents supplied by the Minister and counsel under Exhibit 5, pg. 8, there is an outstanding warrant out for the Claimant for his failure to attend his court proceedings in the U.S. There is also indication that as a result, he violated his bond as per Exhibit 9, pg. 1.
[37] As the Claimant did not attend the court proceedings and we do not have any other documents relating to the outcome of the proceedings, the panel has no further information to make a further assessment in this regard.
The facts surrounding the crime:
[38] The Claimant did not dispute the details of the accident. His account seems to be in line with the police summary report.
[39] It appears that the primary cause of the accident is the failure of the Claimant to give full attention to the roadway and the traffic conditions. Claimant's counsel argues that it is unfortunate that the accident took place and that someone was killed and others injured however, the event appears to be accidental.
The mitigating circumstances and aggravating circumstances underlying the conviction
[40] The Minister argued some aggravating circumstances for consideration as follows:
[41] The Claimant was driving a large motor vehicle. The Claimant's actions resulted in one fatality and injuries to 18 others.
[42] Counsel to the Claimant argues that this was an unfortunate accident. There is no evidence that the Claimant was under the influence. This was echoed by the police summary report.
[43] The Minister indicates that based upon the PC's testimony, the panel should find that the "serious reasons for considering" test has been met.
[44] One important factor that the panel considered is the Claimant's claim that he was not aware that he was charged nor that the matter had not been settled at the time of his move to New York.
[45] The panel asked whether the Claimant contacted his lawyer back in the U.S., to confirm the allegations brought forth by Canadian immigration officials in 2017 at the time he was advised of the missed court date and pending warrant. He testified that it had been a long time and he was not aware of how to get in touch with the lawyer. He testified that the friend who assisted him had previously passed away. He was asked if he had contacted his sister back in the U.S. to try and get information about pending charges relating to the accident. He noted that his sister is always busy and as such, had not been able to do so.
[46] The Claimant may not have known prior to 2017 about the situation back in the U.S. but at the point he was advised of the situation, there is no indication that he made any attempts to either clear his name, if in fact he did not face any charges as he believed or in the alternative, to find out the real situation and possibly, make things right by facing the consequences of his actions.
[47] The panel finds that the facts surrounding the commission of the crime do not lessen the Claimant's personal responsibility. He ought to have paid more attention to the roadway and carefully considered his driving speed in light of the traffic conditions and his years of driving experience.
[48] Further, it is not likely that his lawyer in the United States did not advise him that there were charges pending as a result of the above accident. It is possible that the lawyer wanted to get in touch with the Claimant but as he indicated, he did not advise the courts nor his lawyer that he had moved to a different jurisdiction in the country. The Court in Delaware issued a warrant for his arrest when he did not appear for the trial. If his presence at a trial was not required, the court would not have issued a warrant for his arrest.
[49] The panel notes that the Claimant continues to flee justice in the U.S. as he has not returned there to face the charges. Even if he did not know about these charges and the warrant until 2017, he has known about it since then.
[50] The Claimant's flight from prosecution and justice is a significant aggravating factor in this case.
[51] The panel finds that, based upon the above undisputed evidence, and given that the maximum sentence in Canada would be life imprisonment under section 320.21, the panel finds the offence committed by the PC should be considered serious and that the burden of proof of "serious reasons for considering" under Article 1F(b) has been met.
[52] Given this disregard for public safety and flight from prosecution and justice, the panel finds the Claimant's offence is serious for the purposes of Article 1F(b) exclusion.
[53] Accordingly, based on the above analysis, the PC is excluded from refugee protection pursuant to section 98 of the IRPA, in that there are serious reasons for considering that he has committed a serious non-political crime outside of Canada within the meaning of Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention.
[54] The Federal Court has ruled that only if a Claimant is not excluded from refugee protection should the merits of a refugee claim be examined.xxi Therefore, there will not be an inclusion analysis.
CONCLUSION
[55] Having considered all the evidence, the panel finds that there are serious reasons for considering that the Claimant has committed a serious non-political crime outside of Canada. The panel therefore finds that Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention applies, by virtue of section 98 of the IRPA, thereby excluding the Claimant from refugee status and the status of a person in need of protection.
[56] His claim is therefore rejected.
(signed)

REASONS FOR DECISION
[1] This is the decision regarding an application filed by the Minister of Public safety under section 109 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)1 to vacate and nullify the Convention refugee status conferred in the refugee protection claim of the respondent, XXXX XXXX XXXX (A.K.A. XXXX XXXX), (A.K.A. XXXX XXXX), (A.K.A. XXXX XXXX XXXX), on November 12, 2003.
DETERMINATION
[2] After considering the evidence, the panel grants the Minister's application under section 109 of the IRPA. The panel determines that the decision of the Refugee Protection Division on November 12, 2003, conferring refugee protection to the respondent is nullified.
BACKGROUND
[3] The Respondent's Personal Information Form (PIF) narrative2 states that his name is XXXX XXXX, that he was born in Sudan on XXXX XXXX, 1975, and that he resided in Sudan until his escape to Canada on XXXX XXXX, 2003 where he claimed refugee protection. His refugee protection was granted by the RPD on November 12, 2003.
[4] The Minister submits that the then claimant misrepresented his true identity and asylum status in the United States. That in fact a comparison of fingerprints concluded that he was the same person as XXXX XXXX, a resident of the United State who was conferred Asylum in 2001.
[5] The respondent asserts that XXXX XXXX is his brother and that the evidence provided by the Minister is flawed.
ANALYSIS
[6] Section 109 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act states that:
(1) The Refugee Protection Division may, on an application by the Minister, vacate a decision to allow a claim for refugee protection, if it finds that the decision was obtained as a result of directly or indirectly misrepresenting or withholding material facts relating to a relevant matter.
(2) The Refugee Protection Division may reject the application if it is satisfied that other sufficient evidence was considered at the time of the first determination to justify refugee protection.
(3) If the application is allowed, the claim of the person is deemed to be rejected and the decision that led to the conferral of refugee protection is nullified.
Minister's Application
[7] In the Notice of Application to Vacate dated December 3, 20133, the Minister alleges that the respondent obtained refugee status in Canada by misrepresentation, by concealment of material facts, particularly regarding his identity and his immigration status in the United States.
[8] The Minister provided additional documents to its application to vacate on March 12, 20194 .
[9] On November 6, 2003 the respondent XXXX XXXX was found to be a Convention Refugee by the Immigration and Refugee Board's Refugee Protection Division.
[10] The Minister's application indicates that the respondent misrepresented his identity and USA Refugee Protection status. The Minister has provided evidence in Exhibit 2,9,10,11,13,14,18 that shows that the result from a fingerprint comparison between XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX concluded that the respondent XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX resident of the United States are "one and the same person".
[11] The Minister provided additional facts showing that both XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX list XXXX XXXX as their spouse; evidence that XXXX XXXX XXXX was caught using XXXX identity; travel history for the respondent while using both identities; omissions on the respondent's PIF and PR applications of an alleged brother named XXXX.
[12] Furthermore, the Minister submits that the claimant was living under both identities after evidence was found in a package sent in XXXX 2010 by the respondent's spouse XXXX XXXX to an associate in Edmonton. The package contained documents addressed to XXXX XXXX including USA refugee travel documents and other ID issued to XXXX XXXX with the instruction from the respondent's spouse to forward them to "my husband".
[13] Further the respondent was caught in XXXX 2011 by USA Custom Border Patrol traveling as XXXX XXXX to the USA and carrying XXXX XXXX PR card in his shoe and other incriminating evidence.
[14] The Minister further submits that when the claimant returned to Canada on XXXX XXXX 2019, he was only in possession of a Sudanese passport containing no visas, and that he provided unreliable information regarding his PR card.
The respondent
[15] The respondent rejects the allegation made by the Minister that he is the same person as XXXX XXXX and that he concealed the fact that he had previously obtained refugee status in the US in 2001. The respondent submits that XXXX XXXX is in fact his brother.
[16] The respondent submits that the Minister did not meet his burden of proof and that the evidence presented by the Minister is insufficient to support the allegation that the respondent XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX are the same person and not brothers.
[17] The respondent submits that the fingerprint evidence is problematic and suggests that there may have been a mix up and that the 2 sets of fingerprints both belong to the respondent XXXX XXXX.
[18] The respondent submitted further evidence that he was in Canada at the time material to this application. The respondent submitted an airport booking, and medical evidence (ex 19). He also submitted biodata pages of passports of both XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX containing different nationality numbers, evidence that the respondent was in Canada, as well as other supporting evidence listed in par. 14-23 of counsel's post hearing submissions which were duly considered by the panel.
Considerations
[19] The panel is aware that the consequences of a vacation application are very serious. The panel took into consideration and carefully and deeply analysed all the evidence submitted in this case, including the oral testimony of all the parties and the witness. The panel instructed both the Minister's counsel and counsel for the claimant to provide further evidence to clarify the identity issue of the respondent
[20] Based on the material in the Minister's application and supporting disclosure5 which include a biometric match and further evidence, the panel is satisfied on the balance of probabilities that the Minister has proven its case and that the evidence provided by the Minister reveal on the balance of probabilities that the respondent XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX are one and the same person.
[21] The panel reviewed thoroughly the evidence provided by the respondent. The evidence provided by the respondent is not enough to clarify and rebut the evidence put forth by the Minister with regard to the identity of the respondent. Based on the evidence, I am not satisfied on the balance of probabilities that XXXXand XXXX are two different persons.
[22] I have looked at the other evidence and I have the following concerns:
* The respondent and his alleged brother have the same first name, which in itself is concerning, and the explanation with regard to his maternal uncle provided by the respondent was not satisfactory;
* The respondent listed six siblings in his PIF. They all have the same last name XXXX, and the explanation as to why XXXX XXXX would be the only sibling with a different last name was not satisfactory;
* The respondent did not list a sibling called XXXX XXXX in his PIF and the explanation that he was told to only list the name of relatives who don't have status because they can apply for family reunion is not satisfactory as he has listed a brother XXXX XXXX who already obtained asylum in the USA;
* The respondent listed in his CIC Niagara Falls Refugee intake Form (ex 1) in page 3 a mother and 3 brothers and 3 sisters as his family outside Canada, omitting one alleged sibling XXXX XXXX.
* The respondent XXXX XXXX was not called as a witness in his alleged brother's US legal proceedings;
* Both alleged brothers listed XXXX XXXX as their spouse;
* Possession of identity documents and information pertaining to both identities.
[23] I have reviewed the rest of the evidence as indicated by counsel in his submission and I am not persuaded on the balance of probabilities that they are sufficient to rebut the Minister's assertion and evidence
* The respondent's passport of the respondent or his alleged brother was found to have been altered;
* The passport used by the respondent to enter Canada recently contains no visas and no PR card was presented. It also contains some contradictory information such as the place of birth of the respondent who listed in his refugee application that he was born in Karma, and his recent passport shows Bergeeg;
* As pointed out by the Minister, the medical evidence submitted to show that the respondent was in Canada at times material to the application contains contradictory information and seems to have been altered; therefore, I cannot rely on it, and this casts a doubt on all the evidence provided by the respondent to show that he was residing in Canada.
[24] Based on the evidence the panel finds that the respondent's identity and status in the USA were concealed from the original RPD panel. Because of that, the panel is also satisfied that there was no other sufficient evidence that was before the original RPD panel that would have been sufficient to justify refugee protection.
[25] Therefore, the panel finds that, on a balance of probabilities, the respondent's Convention refugee decision was obtained as the result of misrepresentation and the withholding of material facts relating to a relevant matter and that there was no other sufficient evidence before the original panel of the RPD that would have been sufficient to justify refugee protection.
CONCLUSION
[26] The panel grants the Minister's application to vacate the respondent's status as a Convention refugee, pursuant to section 109 of the IRPA, and his claim is deemed to be rejected and the decision that led to the conferral of refugee protection is nullified.
